TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling for questions without notice, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery this afternoon of a delegation from the United Kingdom branch of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. The delegation is led by Sir Angus Maude. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to you, one and all, a very warm and cordial welcome to Australia and this Senate chamber today. —I ask Senator Chaney, Minister for Social Security and Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, whether the number of people on unemployment benefit in Australia is now 466,000 as at last month? Is that figure some 70,000 above the monthly average forecast in the Budget which was brought down in August? Is it also 6,000 above the recently revised estimates provided by the Treasurer to the House of Representatives? If the Budget figures in relation to unemployment levels were not deliberately falsified as part of the Government's plan for an early election, how can the Minister justify such enormous discrepancies in the estimates which have been made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent figure I have available is for October when 465, 959 were in receipt of the unemployment benefit. I think that is approximately the figure which the Leader of the Opposition mentioned in his question. The current estimate accepted by the Government is under consideration. A revised figure was announced by the Treasurer some time ago. The most recent information I have is that the Treasurer again has updated revisions before him and is giving them some consideration. It is quite clear that there has been a significantly worse result than was anticipated at the time of the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: I reject again the suggestion that there was a falsification of figures at the time of the Budget. As a Minister who was involved in the Government's decision as to the acceptance of a figure on which to base Budget figuring, I can only say that we took the advice which was available to us. I do not know of any observer who was predicting the sort of rapid deterioration which has occurred since August. Senator Button may have had some private advice on the subject, but certainly the advice which was available to me and the Government at that time was not that there would be anything like the increase which has occurred. The point needs to be made, I think, for the sake of people who are subject to unemployment benefit, that the payment of unemployment benefit is not affected by the Budget figuring. Unemployment benefit is, of course, automatically paid to those who are entitled to it. I will respond to the rest of the question when I have had a chance to consult the Treasurer who is, as I said before, considering the latest information available to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In December 1976 the Prime Minister requested Sir Bede Callaghan to report to the Government on the structure of Tasmanian industry and the employment situation. An interdepartmental committee under the chairmanship of Mr A. J. Woods recently upgraded this report. What has been the result? What is the current state of the committee's operations? Will the committee continue to sit? Has a report been produced? When will one become available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that, recognising that Tasmania had major disabilities compared with mainland States, the Federal Government adopted a particular policy concerning its approach to Tasmania and, based on that, set up the Callaghan Inquiry into the Structure of Industry and the Employment Situation. The report of that inquiry recommended in November 1977 a program of special assistance. The special assistance projects under this program amount to some $10m, and they have been approved. Under present policy guidelines Commonwealth special assistance is to complement Tasmanian initiatives in industrial development and is conditional upon an element of Tasmanian self-help in the proposals. The proposals are considered by a Commonwealth-State officials committee, chaired by the Secretary to the Department of National Development and Energy, which last met on 10 March of this year. At that meeting two proposals which are now under study were noted. One concerns an essential oils industry for Tasmania and the other concerns a maritime heritage centre in Launceston. The Prime Minister and the Premier agreed in 1981 to a review of the existing arrangements and progress with the special assistance scheme. A draft report on the results of this review is at present under consideration. I have a list of the various matters that have been undertaken. Perhaps it would be simpler, rather than delay the Senate, to seek leave to have the list incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
SPECIAL ASSISTANCE PROJECTS
Native Forest Development-Total loans over five years from 1978-79 will amount to $1.08m. ($136,000 in 1978-79, $236,000 p.a. for the next four years).

Development of the Fishing Industry-a Fishing Port Development Study has been recently completed at a cost of $23,453 and the results are under study by the Tasmanian Government. Depending on the outcome of the study further Commonwealth assistance could be sought.
Pilot Industrial Estate, Launceston-a loan of $195,000 was made to assist in the development of a pilot industrial estate at Legana. The project is funded on a dollar for dollar basis with the State.
Launceston Precision Tool Annexe-a loan of $343,000 was made for additional equipment needed at the relocated Annexe.

Port Arthur-Commonwealth assistance of up to $6m will be provided on a $2 for $ 1 basis as part of a seven year program for the restoration and development of Port Arthur as a major national tourist site.

Under the Commonwealth Regional Development Program loans totalling $1.802m were approved for eight Tasmanian projects, including two tourist development projects. Following the Review of Commonwealth Functions the Program is being phased out.
Acceleration of mineral and coal exploration-the Commonwealth provided $200,000 for an accelerated program by the Tasmanian Department of Mines.
Centre for Regional Economic Analysis at the University of Tasmania- Commonwealth is providing $40,000 per year for four years, on a $1 for $1 basis, from 1981-82 for the establishment of the Centre.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. It refers to the appointment of Mr J. W. von Doussa on 11 October to inquire into the financial affairs of Mr Denis Horgan. I ask: What power to subpoena documents does Mr von Doussa have for the purpose of this inquiry? What protection from defamation action does Mr von Doussa, his inquiry and, ultimately, his report have? Will the Acting Attorney-General table the letter written to Mr von Doussa setting out his terms of appointment? Will he give an undertaking to table the report as soon as it is completed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arrangement with respect to Mr von Doussa-I have not been directly involved in setting it up, so I speak from my general knowledge of the subject-is, as I understand it, a consensual one. There has been an agreement between the Government and Mr Horgan that, in order to put these matters to rest , there should be an investigation of his affairs by an independent counsel. Mr von Doussa has agreed to do that. It is something which is being done with the active co-operation of Mr Horgan. I understand that that co-operation includes making available whatever is requested and giving Mr von Doussa access to Mr Horgan's advisers. As I understand it, there is no formal power to subpoena. There has not been an appointment of any sort which would give rise to any form of statutory or common law powers to subpoena documents. Rather, there is a consensual arrangement whereby an independent counsel of high reputation will examine the matter and report to the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as protection from defamation action is concerned, I am relieved that I am not permitted under the Standing Orders to give legal opinions because, representing the Acting Attorney-General, I would be doubtful about advising Mr von Doussa on the law of defamation. But again I should have thought that that would not give rise to difficulties in this case. At the request of two interested parties-namely, the Commonwealth and Mr Horgan-Mr von Doussa is conducting an examination in accordance with certain terms of reference which have been given to him. I should not have thought that any problem would arise with respect to defamation.

As far as the third and fourth parts of the question are concerned-the question of the tabling of a letter and of any results of Mr von Doussa's examination-I will refer them to the Acting Attorney-General for reply. I have not seen any letter of appointment and I am not aware of whether or not one exists. It probably does exist. I will examine that matter and ask the Acting Attorney- General to give me a reply to the third and fourth parts of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. In the event of Mr von Doussa producing findings which are adverse to Mr Horgan, will Mr von Doussa have the same protection against possible action for defamation that Mr Costigan had when his report was presented to the Government and that Messrs McCabe and Lafranchi had when their report was presented to the Victorian Government? If not, what protection, if any, will Mr von Doussa have?

—As I said before, I do not propose to breach the Standing Orders by endeavouring to give a legal opinion which might be a suspect opinion anyway. There is clearly no privilege, in a statutory sense, in a matter such as this. There may well be questions of qualified privilege which might arise where there is a matter of common interest and where a person is acting at the request of parties but that is a matter of law on which I do not think that I could give the Senate a definite opinion even if the Standing Orders permitted it. If Mr von Doussa has problems with respect to defamation and so on I have little doubt that he will raise those matters with the Acting Attorney-General or the Attorney-General if he is back in place at that time. I proffer the view that I do not believe difficulties will arise in this area. If they do no doubt they will be matters which the counsel concerned will raise with the Attorney-General for the Government's consideration.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Education been drawn to the lack of employment opportunities in Australia for graduates who have majored in oriental languages, even if those graduates have had additional language experience overseas? Is it true that Federal Government departments such as the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs, the Joint Intelligence Organisation and the Office of National Assessments regard such language skills as supplementary to other qualifications and therefore unnecessary? Does not the private sector prefer as interpreters foreign-born nationals who have English as their second language so that employment opportunities for Australian graduates majoring in oriental languages for practical purposes are restricted to teaching other students, thus perpetuating this employment disaster? Will the Government consider a survey to compare job opportunities with the number of students currently taking majors in oriental languages so that young Australians who put many years into studying these languages will not be misled? Finally, does the Minister agree that there are many benefits in studying foreign languages but job opportunities in Australia is not one of them?

—Senator Lewis drew to my attention several examples of some people who have had difficulty in getting employment so the answer to his question about whether my attention has been drawn to several events has to be yes. I thank Senator Lewis for making several examples known to me. I cannot comment on whether departmental priorities or practices in departments nominated by the honourable senator are as set out by him but I have no reason to doubt that they are. Issues which relate to the employment of graduates who have Asian languages have been taken under study and were among matters raised in a report in 1980-the Fitzgerald report 'Asia in Australian Education', a report to the Asian Studies Association of Australia. That report is still under study and is still being considered. It was a report to a particular association and the Government will be hearing from and working with that Association on how we should respond to those recommendations. The honourable senator asks in his question whether we should set up an inquiry. I remind him that the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts has under way at present an inquiry into a national language policy.
—This is a specific term of reference.

—I thank Senator Teague, as Chairman of that Committee, for his interjection. He said that it is a specific term of reference to cover the area which has been raised by my colleague. Not only is it a matter of concern and interest to him, but also it is already acknowledged as being of concern and importance to the Senate. The Senate Standing Committee will be taking that matter under study. I think it is reasonable to expect that the Senate Standing Committee will include among its concerns the question of employment prospects for graduates with Asian language skills. I understand that in recent times there have been difficulties for university graduates with Asian language skills in obtaining appropriate employment but we do not have at the moment systematic or authoritative information of a quantitive kind that I can make available to the honourable senator.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce been drawn to Press reports that the European Economic Community has agreed to reduce steel imports by 3 per cent? What effect will this decision have on Australian steel exports to the EEC countries, which in 1980-81 totalled more than $40m? Is it correct that the EEC was able to reduce imports under the terms of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade because the domestic consumption of steel had fallen? Since the Australian domestic consumption of steel has fallen dramatically over the last year why has the Government declined to reduce imports of steel as the Australian market has shrunk instead of simply freezing them, thus effectively increasing the share of steel imports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report referred to by the honourable senator in his question. In a sense it is a reminder of the very great danger which we face around the world with country after country or region after region closing down its trade and further restricting world trade in a way which will damage the long term interests of this country. I think that the most partisan person in the Senate would probably agree that if world trade was in a healthier situation we would not be facing many of the economic difficulties that are causing us so much concern today. The point raised by the honourable senator underlines the difficulties which governments face in this time and the danger that a series of measures will be adopted, whether by countries or trading blocs , which will further reduce world trade.

ANSWER.PARA: It was that sort of consideration which was in our mind when we faced the very difficult question of what response should be made domestically to the obvious difficulties of our own steel industry. We opted to freeze the level of imports rather than to reduce them because we are, currently in GATT discussions of course, trying to ensure that world trade is not further impeded in the way that I indicated earlier in this answer. In making decisions of this sort one is caught with a difficult balance. We, as a trading country, have more of an interest than almost any other country in maintaining the free flow of goods around the world. If Australia, in any sense, sets the lead in closing down trade I believe we will suffer very severely for it. I think the reasoning behind our original decision is clear. The Industries Assistance Commission is further considering this matter. As I said earlier, I understand that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd will be making a further submission to the IAC and no doubt these matters will again come before the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am not clear whether the Minister was implying that Australia should set itself up as an example to the EEC as to how trade relationships should be conducted, particularly in the area of metal products and steel production.
—Mr President, that is more in the nature of a comment.

—Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise whether any consideration has been given or can be given to the proposal of providing full tax deductions of interest payments on housing as a means of stimulating a revival in the home building industry? Does the Minister agree that such a scheme would boost those industries ancillary to the housing industry and also provide more employment opportunities? Does the Minister agree that the resultant almost immediate private savings and the eventual tax return to the Government would more than offset any Budget deficit which might temporarily occur?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of what cost would be involved in full tax deductibility for housing interest. It will probably be recalled that earlier in the year-I think March or April-a housing assistance scheme was introduced and then later, in the Budget in August, an alternative scheme was introduced that could be used for partial deductibility of interest. I think the total cost of what now is on the books is about $400m odd in a year, so I imagine if we were to embrace full tax deductibility for housing interest it would be at considerable cost. I do not doubt that stimulus to the housing industry and ancillary industries for that matter is desirable and that can be achieved in a number of ways. In the introduction of the housing interest deductibility that is now in place consideration was given to assisting those who are in most need, those who may be paying the high rates of interest or those who, in the early years of the purchase of their first home, have considerable expenses. I will draw Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question to the attention of the Treasurer but, as I said, with the Budget just barely passed, there is no proposal at this stage to allow full tax deductibility.

Will the Minister now table the details of all agreements and understandings that may exist between the Commonwealth, Western Australia and Queensland relating to the processing of human rights and racial discrimination complaints? In doing so will he explain how differential treatment can ever be justified in the application and enforcement of Federal laws?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, who is no doubt one who recognises that any exposure to sunlight causes some damage to some skin cells and that ultraviolet light should be reduced for people wherever possible. As many people-I look around here and see there are a few others like myself who have very efficient solar collectors on the tops of their heads-who tend to use sunscreens very regularly would like to be certain that the sunscreening agent that is contained in that cream does not damage their skin, does the Department of Health issue a list of reccommended creams or ingredients for creams? If not, will the Minister ask the Department to do so? In view of the dangers of skin cancer in this country would it be wise to advertise those Department of Health recommendations?

—I understand that the dangers of ultraviolet light are real and that Australia in fact leads the world in having the highest incidence of melanoma and a number of these conditions which are affected by sunlight. The way of minimising the damage does not, of course, rest solely with having a good genetic make-up that leaves one with plenty of hair. It also relates to taking measures to minimise exposure. For example, I understand that a prominent couple in Queensland have advertised a His and Her hat that has been worn-a Joh and Flo hat. That is one efficient way to try to cut down the incidence of skin cancer caused by the sun. I know that some dermatologists of my acquaintance are urging people to make greater use of hats when exposed to the sun.
—Table the hat.

—It is suggested that I should table the hat, Mr President. I wish I had one here. In relation to Senator Townley's efficient solar collector, the question of skin creams or blocking agents to stop the incidence of cancer is important. I think the Department of Health has produced a list on at least one occasion. It might do so on a regular basis; I do not know. Some of the agents which are available are more effective than others. Some of them are relatively ineffective. It is important for those who are going to use some kind of agent to try to stop undue exposure to know which are the effective agents. I will ask the Minister whom I represent whether there is a list extant which can be made available to my colleague. I will pass on the quite excellent and positive comments which have been made by Senator Townley for the Minister's consideration.

—I take the unusual step of under Standing Order 98 addressing my question to Senator Mason who is in charge of the World Heritage Properties Protection Bill which is listed on the Notice Paper. I refer to statements made by Tasmanian Australian Democrat, Norm Sanders, which made great play of Senator Mason's world heritage legislation and in which he stated that Tasmania is a banana republic and a third rate State which is incapable of managing its own affairs. Is not Senator Mason's world heritage legislation predicated on similar assumptions? Will Senator Mason dissociate himself and his colleagues from Dr Sanders's statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I by no means dissociate myself from the tremendous efforts of my colleague Dr Norman Sanders in Tasmania on behalf of the welfare of Tasmania and its protection against the current but temporary ascendancy of barbarians there. I have seen some comments by Mr Gray in this morning's Mercury. If I were Dr Sanders, having read those comments I would see my lawyer. Dr Sanders is a totally dedicated conservationist and a patriotic Tasmanian whose views on the Gordon-below-Franklin dam are, I am quite sure, shared now by the majority of Tasmanians. I think that is something that Mr Gray has to learn. I agree with Dr Sanders to the extent that if Mr Gray goes on being Premier of Tasmania for too long, in spite of the resilience, beauty and natural advantages of that island he will make Tasmania a banana republic. His attitude to this dam and his complete irresponsibility towards its economics and towards conserving the thing which has been given into his trust-that is, Tasmania, with its beauty and heritage-show him to be a man of very small achievements. I hope that he either leaves the scene quickly or demonstrates that he has rather better aims than have been apparent to date.

ANSWER.PARA: Dr Sanders is as angry as I am at the pattern of destruction that is already being carried out in Tasmania by the Hydro-Electric Commission on Mr Gray's specific orders. Mr Gray is not prepared to wait and see what the rest of the people of Australia want; he just wants to get in there and destroy things as fast as he possibly can. He is destroying the area in a careless way because there is evidence already-gathered, I might say, by Dr Norman Sanders, the only person to do so-that an oil slick 5 kilometres long has occurred on the Gordon River. That has happened because of the carelessness of the Hydro-Electric Commission in the use of a pile driver alongside the river. It used that pile driver in such a way as to allow more than 2,000 litres of oil to leak into one of Australia's most beautiful rivers. It seems to me that those honourable senators who are from Tasmania ought to look again at the dismal efforts and paltry performance of this man who has made these comments about Dr Sanders. As for Dr Sanders, I am in no doubt whatsoever that he has the interests of Tasmania at heart. He may be from another country-he comes originally from the United States of America-but he has been around the world enough to know when he has something good. He wants to continue living in Tasmania-he has told me that many times-because he sees it as a place of great beauty and he wants to see that beauty preserved in the interests of his own children and the children of other Tasmanians.

As for my Bill, it has been brought forward merely to construe into law the obligations which the Tasmanian Government and the Federal Government have already incurred under the terms of the world heritage movement. The Bill does no more than that. What are we going to do? We have a world heritage movement. Mr Gray says: 'This is great; let us have it, as long as it applies only to other people'. Would it be perfectly okay, for instance, if Mr Bjelke-Petersen suddenly found out-I know he would not do this-that a very valuable product was to be found in ground-up coral and said he would systematically mine the coral in the Great Barrier Reef? Similarly, perhaps Ayers Rock could be ground up for gravel! Of course, Mr Gray would object to those things. The basic point is that the South West Tasmanian region is part of Australia. Mr Gray is not the Premier of some republic off to the south of Australia. He is an Australian, like all of us, and he has an obligation to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that the document quoted from by Senator Mason be tabled.
—Senator McLaren is welcome to it. It is just some notes.

—I refer the Minister for National Development and Energy to an article in today's Sydney Daily Telegraph which is headlined: 'Work stops on $ 40m Split Rock Dam'. The article claims that a New South Wales funding crisis has stopped the development of the $40m dam in the north of the State. The article reports that the delay is due to the Federal Government's refusal to put up its half of the development money in a lump sum. It states that if the Federal Government would come across with the money the State could go ahead with the project. Further, it states that the Federal Government has allocated $ 2.5m to the project in the past two years of which the State has received only $ 250,000. This is a circumstance of great importance, not only for water availability but also for employment in the area. Will the Minister comment on these significant allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article in this morning's Press. Indeed, the claims by the State people are quite fallacious. The fact is that money is passed to the States for water resources under the Commonwealth Government's National Water Resources Program. Under that program the arrangements are that there will be a dollar for dollar grant-that is, a dollar from the Commonwealth matched by a dollar from the States-that the States will put forward a priority list and the amounts of money available will be reviewed by the Commonwealth in terms of that priority list. The fundamental situation is that it has been agreed by all States and by the Commonwealth since the formation of this program that this should be a year by year decision. It has never been envisaged that there would be any commitment by either the Commonwealth or an individual State for the total cost of any water resource program at the start of any year. Because it is a matching grants program it is reviewed year by year.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1980-81 the Commonwealth provided, on the basis of priorities recommended by the New South Wales Government, half a million dollars for work on the Split Rock Dam. This amount was matched by the State Government and spent. There is no question of any long term commitments at all. In 1981-82, under exactly the same program, the Commonwealth Government provided a further $1.5m to New South Wales towards the approved work on the Split Rock Dam. In fact, the New South Wales Government drew only $250,000 for work on the dam. I repeat that we allocated $1 .5m which could have been taken up and spent. This year the Commonwealth Government has offered $1m to the New South Wales Government. However, the New South Wales Government has decided to introduce, unilaterally, its own decision making on this. It has said that the State has decided not to proceed with the construction of the Split Rock Dam until there is a long term commitment from the Commonwealth Government to meet half the full cost of the dam under the National Water Resources Program.

I repeat that that program is accepted by all the States and in the year by year grants does not make full term commitments to meet half the full cost of any program. Each year submissions are made by the States. They are reviewed and according to priorities there is a matching program. The fact is that the New South Wales Government has had offered to it a considerable amount of money, $1. 5m, of which it has spent a handful, and another $1m which it has not taken up. It has not taken it up because it has decided unilaterally on a principle which is not part of this program at all. The State Government knows very well that the Australian Water Resources Council, of which all the States are members, has looked at this question for the future of long term commitments for particular projects and has asked the survey group that is doing the perspective of water to the year 2000 to look at methods by which long term commitments can be made.

Quite clearly governments, both State and Federal, cannot commit themselves indefinitely to full term programs. I repeat: What has been said is not accurate at all. There is no mote in the Federal Government's eye. The Federal Government has conformed precisely with the terms of the National Water Resources Program. Each year it has offered a significant amount of money. Each year that money could have been put to work. The fact that the money is not being put to work means that a number of Australians who could be employed are not working. It means that the Split Rock Dam is not being built at this moment although it could be built.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the further threat of unemployment facing workers at the Newcastle steelworks? There has been a recent retrenchment of 128 workers and there is a likelihood that more workers will face the loss of their jobs before Christmas. Added to this is a statement by the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that it wishes to cut its work force by a further 1,730 by the end of the year. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether any discussions have taken place between senior members of this Government and BHP in an effort to redress the threat of unemployment facing the 1,730 workers from BHP?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a tragic fact for Australia that the Australian steel industry is suffering a major decline. That is happening for a number of reasons. One reason is the world-wide recession and a very great fall-off in the demand for steel. In the free world alone there is a surplus capacity of about 150 million tonnes a year or more. There is an enormous surplus capacity around the world. The second factor is that a number of countries are, in fact, very competitively exporting. It is suggested that some, for example Korea, may be subsidising their steel and their steel prices in order to win foreign exchange. Countries such as South Korea, facing an enormous problem in funding their foreign exchange because of their imports of oil, are very heavily in debt in that regard. The result is that the world at large has not only a glut of steel but also very keenly priced steel. Australia cannot, of course, compete in world markets on that basis. There has been a Temporary Assistance Authority inquiry and the Government has taken certain steps. The matter is being referred to the Industries Assistance Commission for an overall look.

ANSWER.PARA: To respond specifically to Senator Jones, the Commonwealth Government is in continuous discussion with the steel industry in an effort to see how there can be a major reconstruction of the steel industry and a bringing about of better efficiency in Australian steel making capacity. That will require a considerable injection of capital. Senator Jones and others will recall that in the last Budget the Government included a provision whereby a company with groups of companies can produce an amalgamated balance sheet. That ought to provide BHP with the capacity to inject some of its oil profit into the steel industry. A considerable number of steps are under consideration at this moment. But the road back for the steel industry will not be an instant one. It will be long term, requiring major reconstruction and, of course, a reduction of the cost factor in Australia-particularly opposition to soaring wages-so that we can keep costs down and be competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. The Minister said that there were continuing discussions in relation to the problems of the steel industry. Specifically, can he inform the Senate of the names of the Ministers who have had discussions with BHP in relation to the 1,730 workers who face the loss of their jobs by Christmas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will need to take that matter on notice. I do not know but I presume that any such discussions would have taken place with the responsible Ministers. I say simply that BHP has had broad discussions with the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and many other Ministers, including me . Indeed, at the officer level BHP is in continuous discussions with various departments. This is a continuing process. I join with Senator Jones in acknowledging the tragedy of the lay-off of those workers. I will need to refer that matter to the responsible Minister and obtain an answer.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. According to an article in the Australian, United States evaluation tests on the FA18 fighter aircraft, which cast serious doubts on the capability of its performance, have prompted the United States Navy to delay formally approving the attack version of the aircraft until these reports have been scrutinised. Has the Australian Government received advice of this delay and, if so, how does it affect Australia's preparations for the 75 FA18s which it has contracted to purchase? Can the Minister also advise whether the Government has yet received a report on the evaluation tests? If so, what is the present situation with regard to the FA18 Hornet aircraft?

—This matter was brought to our attention last week in a number of questions in this place and during debate on the appropriation Bills. Firstly , I can say that no advice has been conveyed to us from the United States Navy in regard to its queries. On the other hand, I am able to confirm that the Department of Defence has received a report on the evaluation tests. This has been analysed by the Department's Tactical Fighter Project Office. It is the view of the Royal Australian Air Force that the report reveals little that was not known at the time of the competitive evaluation and that it in no way affects our selection of, and support for, the FA18 as our new tactical fighter.

—I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether she is aware that during the 1929 Depression wage and salary earners were asked, firstly, to accept a wage freeze, secondly, to accept a direct wage reduction and, thirdly, to work for only three out of four weeks with a resultant wage reduction. In those days, in contrast to today, that policy was part of a work sharing program. Is the Government not aware that that policy deepened the economic crisis and kept the world in a crisis for more than a decade? In those circumstances, is not a mere wage freeze a recipe for worsening unemployment and inflation, both of which are on the increase, contrary to the situation in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — We have had a number of discussions drawing comparisons between 1929 and 1982. If Senator Gietzelt wishes to justify his parliamentary party's attitude to a wage freeze or pause by drawing comparisons that are out of date, let that rest on its own. A meeting of Commonwealth Government Ministers and State Premiers will be held in the next week or so. At that time the Commonwealth Government's proposals will be put forward. The State governments undoubtedly will bring forward their own proposals. We hope that out of that there will be recognition that the wage claims that are being made and have been made have been affecting very adversely employment prospects and opportunities. That may not be accepted by the Australian Parliamentary Labor Party in the Federal sphere, but I think we should await the outcome of the Premiers Conference to see whether different attitudes are held by people who belong to the same party as those who sit opposite. The wage pause, I believe, is one step that may be taken to try to improve the employment prospects of all those who are seeking employment. For the proposal to be dealt with in the way that I understand it was dealt with yesterday by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party seems to me to be very short-sighted and not to have the support that seems to be developing for it in the Australian community at this time.

—Is the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General aware of a reported statement yesterday suggesting that, due to a lack of Commonwealth and State support, Adelaide's community legal services face closure? Does the Minister recognise the valuable and efficient work that is carried out by such services throughout Australia? I believe that can be demonstrated by figures released a year or two ago with regard to the Redfern service indicating that each case cost that service only $8.65? —Community legal services represent a relatively recent innovation in the delivery of legal services. They complement the traditional services which have been provided by State legal aid commissions and by the law societies . Under those traditional schemes there has been a variety of experiments with service delivery, but community legal services represent an approach which certainly is regarded by some of my informants as extremely valuable. I have not had any direct experience of them. The Minister whom I represent in this place is no doubt informed on the matter which Senator Jessop raised in his question. I will ask Mr Neil Brown to give consideration to the matter raised by Senator Jessop and to let him have an early reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Is cargo sent to quarantine inspection fumigated prior to its being opened on Australian soil? If not, what steps are taken to ensure that insects cannot escape upon opening?

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. Inasmuch as Australia's annual inflation level is calculated for the September quarter to be 12.3 per cent and wages increased last year by 15.2 per cent or, for adult males, by 16.9 per cent, and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development inflation average figure last year was 7.8 per cent or, for our major trading partners, 6.5 per cent, is it not natural that Australia's steel is likely to be the second most expensive in the world?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —About 15 or 20 years ago it could have been said that Australia's steel was amongst the cheapest in the world and could trade throughout the world on both its quality and price.
—It became expensive at about the time you came into Parliament.

—The adverse factors set in at about the time the Whitlam Government was having an impact on inflation. Today Australian steel ranks very much as one of the high price steels in the world. This is due to a number of factors, some of which I set out in a previous answer. A number of countries have established brand new steel works, particularly countries like Korea which do not have the built-in obsolescence of the older steel works. The fact is that today Australia is facing higher costs than those of our trading partners. In some cases Australia's rate of inflation is double that of its trading partners. I think Senator Crichton-Browne's figures are correct in contrasting us with the OECD. There is no way in which Australia can trade outwards in steel or any other product until we can get our cost factor down to that which is comparable with those with whom we trade. That is a fundamental matter. It is one of the reasons that at this moment the Commonwealth Government is seeking a wages freeze in Australia in order to bring down the rate of inflation and, therefore, to bring down costs. While inflation remains high interest rates will remain higher. Therefore, capital costs and the refurbishment of industry will become dearer. I support the general thrust of Senator Crichton-Browne's question; it is a fact, and one has to bear down on costs in order to resolve it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security in that capacity and also in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware that in Western Australia poor communication between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service is causing confusion regarding entitlements and delay in the payment of benefits? DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Ryan proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to pursue Education policies which meet contemporary needs.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition raises this matter because it is desperately concerned at the absence of a properly informed debate about education not only in this Parliament but also in society generally today. Clearly the circumstances cry out for such a debate. One has only to look at the labour market, at unemployment figures, at the economy and at the outcomes of various educational institutions at the moment and over the last few years to realise that we ought to be engaged in a properly informed debate about education. The Australian Labor Party is determined to have such a proper debate . We want to debate the educational objectives of our school system and our post -secondary systems. We know that there is a crisis in education in that the education systems are not able to meet either the individual needs of all students or the collective needs of our society and our economy. This view is not only the view of the Australian Labor Party but also the view that has been endorsed and documented in all the major reports on education that have appeared in the last seven years-that is, the seven years of the Fraser Government. Most recently and most pertinently, we have the report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, 'Learning and Earning'. Honourable senators will be familiar with this report and its findings. This report is a damning indictment of Fraser education policies. Along with the reports that succeeded it, it demonstrates that students are dropping out of the education system at an alarming rate because the education system does not meet their needs. But where do they go when they drop out? They go not to jobs, apprenticeships or job training but to unemployment and despair.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party wants to know why this is happening. We want to know what changes are needed in the education system to make them adapt to contemporary needs. The Labor Party wants to know this; teachers want to know it; students want to know it; parents want to know it; and educationists want to know it. But the Fraser Government is not interested in these matters. The Fraser Government is not interested in education or in students. The only interest that the Fraser Government has in this vital area is in discriminatory funding. The Fraser Government's whole educational strategy has been to save money at the expense of public education and to promote its own political fortunes by increasing funding to certain non-government schools whose needs are minimal in comparison with the rest of the non-government and the government sectors.

The Australian Labor Party very much regrets that, instead of a debate about education and contemporary needs, to date we have had a debate about the relative merits of demands of certain private schools for virtually unlimited funding. I must state that these demands are just that-demands. They are not needs as defined by any proper education body; they are simply the wishes, the demands of the beneficiaries of certain schools. We very much regret that the Minister for Education, Senator Peter Baume, has fed this unhealthy debate, has lent his ministerial weight to the unrestrained, selfish demands by the advocates of certain education choices. We very much regret that the Government has no education policy, only a funding policy, and that that funding policy is clearly an inequitable one.

Of course, funding is relevant to what education can provide; of course it is the case that the Federal Government's reduction of real funding for the government school sector has meant that the educational objectives of the government school sector have been harder and harder to attain; of course the Government's financial undermining of our tertiary institutions has meant that the ability of those institutions to change and to adapt to contemporary needs has been hamstrung. We need to look only at what is happening to research and development in our university sector to see the effects of inadequate funding on the economy as a whole. We do not deny that we need to talk about education funding. We do not deny that funds are necessary for a sound, modern, adaptable education system. But what we are totally opposed to is the Government's use of education funding for its own short term political and electoral ends.

An analysis of what the Government has done in terms of education funding clearly shows that it has operated in a preferential way and not in a manner based on the education policies designed to meet the needs of all students. In anticipation of the kinds of rhetoric that the Minister is no doubt going to engage in in a few minutes, let me say this at the outset of this analysis: The Australian Labor Party does not quarrel with the proposition that parents have the right of choice with regard to their children's education, that choice of course being exercised within the normal regulations and criteria that operate in a democratic society. The political right to choose a certain kind of education is similar, however, to the political right to buy a certain sort of car or live in a particular sort of suburb. That political right of choice does not bring with it an automatic right to have that choice subsidised by public funds to an unlimited extent. We must make the distinction between a political right of choice and a legitimate demand for public funding.

It is the view of the Labor Party that in the current economic recession when money is tight not all choices can be subsidised infinitely. Our view is that public money must be spent in the most equitable manner possible. Public money must go to raise the standards in government and non-government schools which do not have at present the resources to give the kind of education that students need to meet contemporary needs, as we state in the wording of the matter of public importance. We cannot countenance the use of public money for schools which are operating well above the level attained by government schools or the majority of non-government schools, the parish schools. It is simply a matter of equity. The schools which have the resources to offer effective education-we admire them, we respect them and we acknowledge the work they are doing-ought not to claim more at this stage and leave the majority of our children deprived. That simple proposition is the basis for the Labor Party's needs policy in education funding.

The Minister will produce a lot of figures in an attempt to show that the Federal Government is spending more money on public education than on private education. Of course, that is simply not the case. The percentage of Federal Government contributions to the total recurrent costs of government schools, for example, has dropped from 10 per cent to 7 per cent. In money terms that is $ 111m. That means that $111m less is available in the government school sectors as a result of Fraser Government policies. How can government schools improve, adapt and respond to contemporary needs while they are being financially undermined in this way? The Government likes to boast-I am sure Senator Baume will repeat this boast in a few minutes-that its expenditure per pupil has gone up, but I must point out that this new ratio of funding to individual pupil does not in fact represent a success for the Government; it is a sign of failure.

Let me explain. The expenditure per pupil has gone up because the total number of pupils has declined. That is the heart of the matter as far as today's education debate is concerned. Schools are not retaining students. The rate of retention has slipped markedly since the early 1970s. I must point out that although the rate of female retention to the end of high school has increased, the rate at which that increase has taken place has dropped and the number of girls proceeding from school to post-secondary training has also decreased. These figures are available in the recently published report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on this matter. Schools are not retaining students; the rate of retention is declining.

The proportion of students proceeding from school to university, of course, is also declining. This is a tragic irony at a time of record high youth unemployment and when people without skills and education on the labour market are finding it hardest of all to crack that labour market. Schools, and to an increasing extent post-school systems, cannot retain students. Why is this happening? This is the question with which we in the Labor Party are concerned. Clearly, schools and tertiary institutions are not offering what students need or what they think they need in contemporary circumstances. Clearly, schools need to change in line with the structural changes that have occurred in the economy, in line with the technological revolution which has had a devastating effect on conventional employment and in line with fundamental social changes which include, for example, a permanent-I stress 'permanent'-high rate of participation in the work force by women of all ages.

Schools must change, yet the level of funding for those schools-that is, the government schools and the majority of non-government schools-has been such that innovation and adaptation simply have not been possible. Increases in Commonwealth general recurrent grants to schools since 1976 have been directed to non-government schools, and the largest increases have gone to the wealthiest non-government schools. Government schools have suffered a decline in real funding in the same period. At this point I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table which demonstrates this trend.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me see the table. I suggest that Senator Ryan continue with her speech while I look at the table, Mr Deputy President.
—Please continue, Senator Ryan.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. The figures are drawn from Schools Commission reports. The percentage increases in Commonwealth general recurrent grants indicate the Fraser Government's priorities. There has been a 259 per cent increase in funding for the most wealthy private schools and a 12 per cent decrease in funding for government schools, which schools, of course, are attended by 78 per cent of all Australian school children. It is regrettable that the Minister for Education has attempted deliberately and mischievously to characterise the Labor Party's stance as an attack on non-government schools. The Labor Party's policy is clearly one of restoring fairness to schools funding . Our policy would clearly benefit not only the 78 per cent of all Australian children attending government schools but also a sizable proportion of the remaining 22 per cent in non-government schools. I do not think Senator Peter Baume is fooling many people. Lest Senator Sir John Carrick be tempted to repeat his remarks of yesterday about the flinching attitude of the Labor Party towards editorials in the Australian Financial Review, I shall quote from the editorial of the Australian Financial Review of 10 November, with which, of course, the Labor Party finds itself in total agreement. The Australian Financial Review stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Education Minister, Senator Baume, warned Catholic parents in Sydney last week that the Labor Party's 'needs' policy for school funding was 'a denial of the well established right' of Australian parents to choose private schools for their children and receive basic grants from the Commonwealth and State Governments.

In attempting to score political points Senator Baume forgot to mention that this open-handed policy, claimed as a prime example of the Liberal Party's ' freedom of choice' philosophy, was of increasing concern to both the Treasury and the Government's education advisers. Federal education outlays in 1981 were $882.6m, rising to $1,066.7m in 1982 and to an expected $1,241m in 1983.

It is not just the march of inflation pushing up education costs to the Federal Government. A significant factor is the ease with which new schools can be registered and . . . the fact that a large number of private schools have managed to have themselves classified or reclassified as Category Three schools that attract the maximum funding. In both 1982 and 1983 the Federal Government will provide greater funds to the private rather than the public sector, a new phenomenon.

A great deal of money has been spent but the money has not been spent equitably and it has not been allocated in such a way as to enable the schools system and the post-school education systems to provide education that students want and need.

The Australian Labor Party is determined to put the education debate back on the rails, that is, to have the debate about education. Let me remind the Senate of the reasons for and the history of massive Federal Government involvement in schools. Honourable senators will recall that until the election of the Labor Government in 1972 Federal Government involvement in schools had been minimal. The incoming Labor Government set up the Interim Committee for the Australian Schools Commission under the chairmanship of Professor Peter Karmel to establish a program and objectives for Federal Government upgrading of schools education in Australia. I remind the Senate of the terms of reference of that inquiry. I take the Senate's time to do this because it seems to me that the whole debate about funding has gone right away from the initial objective of having a Federal schools program. It has deteriorated into this clamouring about freedom of choice, unlimited funds and so forth which was not, of course, why we started a schools commission and why we started Federal Government funding. The terms of reference for the Karmel Committee included the following:
(a) examine the position of both government and non-government primary and secondary schools in all States and in the A.C.T. And the N.T.;

(b) make recommendations to the Minister for Education and Science as to the immediate financial needs of schools, priorities within those needs, and appropriate measures to assist in meeting those needs . . .

In carrying out its task the Committee was instructed to work towards establishing acceptable standards for those schools-government and non- government alike-which fall short of those standards. From the outset the initiative of the Federal Government was to establish standards and then to find ways of assisting schools that fell below those standards to raise those standards. The Karmel Committee report-I recommend it to honourable senators who may be out of touch with this debate-had a very interesting discussion on this question of needs which was then our policy and still is. On page 51 of the Karmel Committee report-I hope that the Minister is paying attention-it is stated:

All needs are relative. The allocation of public funds to primary and secondary schools cannot be defended merely on the basis of subjective assessments by interested parties of what resources they would like to have, without regard to fiscal implications or to differences in existing standards among schools. The needs of particular schools cannot be considered in isolation. A school which already has modern equipment, pleasant buildings and a favourable pupil-teacher ratio may wish to have its services enhanced by, say, the installation of closed circuit television. While this may indeed be an improvement, it must take low priority in relation to the claims of a school whose buildings are decrepit and whose pupils are being taught by ill-prepared teachers without the assistance of ancillary personnel or essential equipment. The economic problem of unlimited ends competing for scarce resources is ever present.

If it was present in 1972, when that definition of needs was written, it is even more present now after we have been in an economic recession for seven years. In this summary of, I believe, a very progressive and excellent report, the Karmel Committee said that it acknowledged that there were serious deficiencies in Australia's schools. It continued:

These deficiencies lie in three broad areas. First, most schools lack sufficient resources, both human and material, to provide educational experiences appropriate to the young in a modern democratic industrial society. Secondly, among schools there are gross inequalities, not only in the provision of resources but also in the opportunities that they offer to boys and girls from varied backgrounds. In particular there are many inner-city schools which draw their pupils from populations that suffer grave socio-economic disadvantage , and there are handicapped children for whom quite inadequate opportunities for schooling exist. Thirdly the quality of education leaves much to be desired. Many teachers have been inadequately trained and the provision for their professional development is frequently meagre. Curricula and teaching methods tend to be unresponsive to differences between pupils and to address themselves to the development of a range of attributes which is narrow in relation to the possibilities of life in a complex technological society. In some schools and school systems the authoritarian and hierarchical atmosphere inhibits the human relationships that should prepare young people for their place in the adult world.

I can see that my time is expiring. Before it does, I wish to say that the deficiencies established in the Karmel Committee's report have been overcome to some extent. The Australian Labor Party is happy to recognise that that is the case. However, such deficiencies have not been overcome totally. The inequalities that existed then still exist. Those inequalities will not be overcome while the Government refuses to address itself to the question of developing education policies to overcome them. Those problems and inequalities will not be overcome and schools will not be able to adapt to contemporary needs , to retain their students, until the Government drops its inequitable and very partisan approach to schools funding and goes back to the Karmel Committee's original report and establishes a program that will truly achieve equal opportunity for all children in schools and in post-secondary education in terms of contemporary needs.
