TALK.START.PARA: —The subject finally determined for today's debate concerns education policies. Anyone listening to the broadcast of the proceedings will be disappointed that so narrow a compass was taken on by Senator Ryan's choosing to re-awaken a very narrow area of debate and disagreement and tending to concentrate on talking only about money and school funding and forgetting a whole lot of other areas of education. I know that Senator Macklin, who is to speak in the debate, has an interest in a whole lot of other areas of education, including research. We, for our part, want to cover a much wider compass. I observe that the honourable senator who led in the debate is now leaving the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators have heard the Opposition expounding the national policy which it announced a week or so ago and which it is trying to sell. The policy is divisive, destructive and unfair. We will make that known to the Australian people at every chance we get. One of my colleagues will discuss later the Australian Labor Party's policy and what it may mean. We will ask whether it will add anything to what the Government is already doing to meet and satisfy contemporary needs. I, for my part, want to demonstrate quite clearly that this Government is pursuing and has pursued over a number of years education policies which are relevant, which are appropriate and which meet the needs of Australian people. Of course we are not dealing with a perfect product. I heard Senator Ryan's remarks about the report which was released recently on the study about learning and earning. One might almost have thought that in expressing her concern she was paraphrasing the Press release which I had put out. She was almost re-expressing that Press release and taking it as her own.

Of course we share concerns about education. We should share concerns. I draw the Senate's attention to a Press release by Senator Macklin some months ago which I want to praise. He spoke about the need for talking together and trying to come to some degree of understanding between us on what is possible in the way of achieving consensus in education. In my approach today I will try to identify some of the national education needs and goals. I will try to demonstrate that not only our expenditure but also our policies are directed towards meeting those needs, towards trying to satisfy them. My colleague Senator Teague, in his contribution later, will discuss some of the specifics of the programs which we fund and which are designed to meet contemporary problems. This is done, of course, so that students at tertiary and secondary levels can cope with the challenges which are all too evident in today's society. As I mentioned, we will be discussing the ALP's rather pathetic policy. That will be done by my colleague Senator Martyr.

What are our national needs? It is quite clear that Australia requires a society with the skills which are necessary to meet what lies ahead, and this skill need is changing, and changing continuously. In addition all Australians need to have the opportunity to develop through education their individual and personal potential both for their own benefit and for the benefit of the wider community. We need a system where quality and excellence are valued. We need an educational system which will help us, as a nation, to comprehend what the challenges are and which will help us to produce a society with enough flexibility to respond to those challenges. In a particular area of education the question of what we do for youth in transition is one of the answers to what is needed but, of course, it is not the only answer for which we are searching.

The Government acknowledges the national needs of this country. We have endorsed a policy which sets out to provide and to fund an educational system to respond to these needs. We do it through schools and through the post-secondary area. In co-operation with the States our policies ensure that there is freedom of choice in the schools area. Our policies increase access to good quality educational opportunity for many children and they have promoted the attainment of acceptable resource standards in government and non-government schools. To achieve these goals we, as a government, are providing in 1983 about $1.25 billion as our share of a national educational cake. This will be an increase in real terms of about 20 per cent since 1976. I will come back in a moment to discuss how that is divided.

Since we have taken government there has been a major increase in our commitment in terms of real money which, after allowing for inflation, goes into supporting schools. We supplement State inputs. We acknowledge that in the schools area the States have primary constitutional responsibility but, of course, much of the money they put into education through their schools comes in the end from Commonwealth grants. The operation of government schools has been such that they have increased their per student expenditure in real terms by about 50 per cent between 1974 and 1981. There has been a real advance in terms of the resources applied in government schools across Australia. We have played our part in this. Our total recurrent funding for government schools has increased in real dollars. If the dollars we applied in 1976 and the dollars we are applying now are looked at and we discount for some appropriate deflator, it will be seen that we are putting more into supporting the running of government schools in Australia-the recurrent funding-than was put in in the last Labor Budget.

In the last Labor Budget $328m-I have adjusted the figures to get them into constant terms-was put into the running of government schools by the Commonwealth. In 1981 we exceeded that figure and put in $330m. In 1982 the figure was $334m and in 1983 it was $339m. Senator Ryan can use any percentage she likes. In the end it is whether more or less money is provided which is important, once inflation has been allowed for. We have increased our support to the government sector for running the schools. We ask that that be acknowledged, not that the figures be twisted. Our commitment is strong and continuing for government schools.

We have increased our support for non-government schools by quite considerable amounts. The honourable senator spent some time concentrating on this. She referred to Labor's policy. It is like an earthquake. There is more moving earth with Labor's policies-about 5.5 on the Richter scale. It is hard to know where one is at any moment. Is it the ALP policy as set out at the biennial conference in July? Is it the Labor policy that is set out in the latest Press release from Western Australia as all the weaseling goes on to try to satisfy this or that interest group that the policy as set out at the Labor conference does not apply to it? Is it the policy that was identified in the National Times using a list that came from ALP sources, now disowned? Is it the policy favouring the limit set out in front of me at a conference recently at which the Labor spokesman talked about schools with fees in excess of $2,500? Is it the policy behind the later announcement when the Labor Party talked about schools with fees in excess of $3,000? Is it the policy behind the recent announcement of the Labor spokesman when he was speaking in Western Australia that no school in Western Australia will be involved?

What is the ALP policy? One thing we know about it is that it is designed to knock off funding for some non-government schools in Australia. That is quite clear; that is explicit. It is designed to take away the funding which goes to support some Australian children today. If one believes the document that came out of the ALP conference-I ask why one would not-that involves up to 96,000 Australian children. That is as I read the document and understand it. I think my understanding is correct. It demonstrates the power of the left wing and of unions such as the Australian Teachers Federation over the policy making of the Australian Labor Party. But the ALP is now discovering that when it tries to articulate into policy what it passed at the conference it will not work. It is unwilling to come up with a list of exactly who are the kids whose funding it would knock off.

The Labor Party's policy is based upon several misapprehensions. First of all, schools in Australia have both assets which they have gathered and incomes which they need to run themselves. The two are quite separate. It is quite possible for a school to be rich in assets and poor in income. I ask honourable senators: If a school's assets are built up over 100 years does it follow that it is a rich school in income terms? Of course it does not follow. Yet the ALP, as much as anyone, has tried to promote the myth that any non-government school-this applies only to non-government schools-which has assets is by definition a rich school. That is a logical absurdity. There are rich and poor schools in terms of assets in both sectors-government and non-government. The Commonwealth contributes in a very major way to the provision of assets. We have traditionally provided up to 30 per cent of what the States use in building their government schools. This year, in my State, because the State Labor Government is withdrawing much of its support for the building of government schools, the Commonwealth's contribution, unacknowledged by the State, will rise to closer to 40 per cent or more of the entire amount spent.

But the debate is not about assets. It is about the income that the schools have available. It is about salaries, because the cost of running schools is the cost of salaries. Here the subservience of the ALP to teacher unions has been most obvious. The unions are creating myths. The fact is that the Commonwealth Schools Commission assesses schools in terms of the amount that they have coming in. It puts those schools into one of three groups, group one being the better off schools and group three being the poorer schools. If the Schools Commission assessed government schools in Australia-the state schools-every government school in Australia would be in group one, the best off group. Most government schools in Australia in terms of resources and income with which to pay teachers to run them are group one schools. Although one would not think so to listen to the nonsense that is talked by our opponents, most government schools, in terms of income with which to run them, are group one schools. They have enough coming in from the State to pay the teachers' salaries. It is the Catholic schools that are poor. Even the non-Catholic independent schools, in terms of income, are poorer schools. Our policies attempt to overcome that relative inequality. The Commonwealth Government tries to support non-government schools on the basis of need. To try to argue that a group one non-government school is rich compared with its government school counterpart down the road is untrue, a lot of nonsense and the basis for a misplaced policy.

Senator Ryan in her speech mentioned the problem of retention of students. Having paraphrased the first part of my Press release she then went on to say how sad it was that schools cannot retain students. She did not give the whole story. Not all schools cannot retain students. There is a problem. It is the government schools that cannot retain children. It is true that there is a falling number of children coming through the schools in the smaller school population. But the independent schools in Australia retain children. The completion rate to year 12 is 85 per cent. The poor Catholic schools which are poorer in every way than their government school equivalents retain children. Their retention rate to year 12 is 45 per cent. It is the government schools system that is failing to retain children. Its retention rate is 30 per cent. Might I say that the excellent Australian Capital Territory education system which I administer has a retention rate to year 12 of 65 per cent. It is the schools operated by State governments that are losing students to the non- government sector and failing to retain students through to year 12.

Perhaps we need to explore and understand why that is so. If I had been less coy when answering Senator Chipp's question last week I might have suggested that there is something in the approach of some teachers in those schools which is causing parents to want to withdraw their children and take them to another system in which they know there will be a teacher every day, in which they know that industrial matters will not interfere with their kid's education and in which they believe the education is, in some way, better. That is a matter of school system funding to which my colleagues will come back and develop further.

The Commonwealth also is a major contributor to other areas of education. It is the sole funding agency for the university and college sector in Australia. It has provided enormous extra input into the technical and further education sector. In fact, in 1983 it will put more than $2,000m into the post-secondary sectors of education, that is the 19 universities, the 44 or 45 colleges after amalgamation and, of course, the TAFE sector. We are providing support, through our funding, for 166,000 university students and 168,000 students in colleges. We are providing our portion of support for 2.3 million children in the government school system, for two-thirds of a million children in the non- government system and for about 700,000 people in TAFE. That measurement is slightly difficult because there may be some double counting. That is where our support goes.

We show the way in other areas in the Australian Capital Territory system. We pioneered a partnership between schools and the community. The Australian Capital Territory school system has a school-based curriculum. There is parent participation in school matters through their involvement in school boards. The Australian Capital Territory has been a pioneer in a system of upper secondary education in secondary colleges. This system has proved to be extremely effective in the education of youth. The Commonwealth, through its own system of education, is helping to show the way. In co-operation with other arms of the portfolio, the Australian Capital Territory system is collaborating in the development of educational initiatives that will ensure that all youths in the Australian Capital Territory have access to satisfying educational experiences either within their schools, within the work place, or through community services. This is to be called Program Youth. Australian Capital Territory schools are also pioneering bilingual education. In 1983, eight of our primary schools will be given supplementary funding to trial bilingual programs. We have announced recently that we will promote and support the French-Australian School -a bilingual school-in the Australian Capital Territory. At Narrabundah College in the Australian Capital Territory we have introduced and are supporting an international baccalaureate program. On a national basis, we have funded a transition program which is represented in the Australian Capital Territory.

In the education area we support school funding, college funding, university funding and technical and further education funding, which has gone up significantly during our period of government. We support students through the provision of student benefits. In this Senate we will be debating and implementing a Bill to provide the option of student loans. We are involved in supporting many programs-programs through the Aboriginal Secondary Education Grants scheme and the Aboriginal Study Grants scheme, programs for isolated children, programs to support more post-graduate students with higher stipends and less onerous conditions, programs to get more students to stay at school by offering a much increased secondary allowance scheme for years 11 and 12, and programs for greater Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowances. We are taking every step we can to enhance and increase educational opportunity in Australia. It distresses us when the debate, advanced by our opponents, concentrates on matters at the margin and tries to say to the Australian people that what the education debate should be about is whether a small group of non- government schools should be punished and to try to call that a national policy.

We accept the debate on this matter of public importance. There is no truth in the statement that there has been a failure by this Government to pursue educational policies; our policies have met contemporary needs. I end by observing that my opponents actually put in two notices today as to what their matter of public importance would be. When they realised that the first one was totally unsustainable and unarguable, the second one emerged. We have demolished it, I think, quite comprehensively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the following matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to pursue education policies which meet contemporary needs.

Listening to the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), I was reminded of Walter Bagehot's description of a statistician who uses figures as a drunk uses a lamp post-for support rather than illumination. I was very sad that the Minister's speech was so much devoted to stunt rhetoric about what this Government has done without any critical examination of the situation of education in Australia and how it has developed in the last few years. I found that the most enlightening part of Senator Baume's speech was the news that Senator Martyr will be brought into battle at the end of the debate to demolish the education policies of the Australian Labor Party. That will give us an opportunity to have the 1950s revisited. I doubt that he would have much understanding of contemporary education issues. Twice in his speech Senator Baume referred to the answers for which the Government is searching. He then devoted most of his remarks to issues of funding, for which he chastised Senator Ryan for referring to at all. The other sad thing about his speech is that it had all those characteristics of the Fraser Government's style about it. As a new Minister, he has learnt quickly to emphasise the most divisive issues rather than those of fundamental importance to an education system and further to find scapegoats for failures of government policy in various sectors of the education system.

I will examine very briefly how it has come about that we get this sort of performance from a Minister in the Fraser Government in 1982-a Minister of a government which has been in power for seven years. The Government's record in education has been as bad as it has been everywhere else. I remind the Senate that the Fraser Government came into power at a time when the basic advisory structure for education, which the Government still retains, of education commissions had been established by a Labor government. It came into power at a time when there were higher participation rates in secondary, university and college education than there are now-that is, a greater proportion of young people were attending those institutions. It came into power at a time when there was a community consensus about the operation of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and about increased equity and opportunity throughout the school system which was operating as a result of decisions and recommendations of the Schools Commission.

In 1976 the Fraser Government, for ideological reasons, decided to turn the process around. If we look at the rhetoric of 1976 and 1977-very ideologically based rhetoric-we find many references to the relationship between education and employment, the need to train people in specific skills. The current ideology of business was that the education system in Australia had failed. The Government picked it up. There was a lot of talk about the education system being a scapegoat for the failure of entrepreneurial skills in Australia and the declining success of Australian business. All of that ideological turnaround ignored what senators on this side of the Senate were saying even then. It ignored enormous technological changes and developments which at that time were, and still are, taking place in Australia. This meant that we had to consider an enormously different range of options for Australian children than this Government was prepared to consider. The emphasis was on the relationship between education and the job market. This was reflected in the terms of reference of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment established in 1976 or 1977. The inquiry report was talked about for two years by spokesman for this Government-by Senator Baume's predecessors-as the document which would provide a blueprint for Australian education until the year 2000. The terms of reference of the Williams Committee of Inquiry contain the specific request for that Committee to give all its emphasis to the relationship between specific education and specific employment. This was flying in the face of the realities of a changing society.

If we talk about those questions to business people today-this may be news for Senator Baume; perhaps he does not have the time-we see that their attitudes have changed entirely. The attitudes of this Government have not changed. The attitudes of business people now, who are very much concerned about growing unemployment, particularly amongst young people, is that there should be much greater Commonwealth expenditure on education. They were saying exactly the opposite in 1976 and 1977. Seven years later one can say that no Government in Australian history has presided over a greater decline in employment and education options for young Australians than the Fraser Government. The only education option which this Government offers as being different from that offered by anyone else and which other speakers in addition to the Minister will no doubt offer, is the option which it has always been very concerned about; that is, the option for some children from wealthy backgrounds to exercise their traditional privilege of attending wealthy schools at public expense. That is the option which the Fraser Government offers young Australian children. It is the only one which identifies it from everybody else in the context of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Poor Catholic parents.
—The Minister should not mutter about poor Catholic schools. They understand the position of the Australian Labor Party much better than Senator Baume is prepared to misrepresent today.

That is the only additional option which this Government offers, because for six years now it has been locked into a narrow view of the function and role of education. SPEECH.PARA: The largest declines in higher education have been 17-19-year-old males in universities and 17-19-year-old females in advanced education. The participation rate for 17-19-year-old males in universities has now fallen to the level of the mid 1960s.

Under the section headed 'Implications for Policy', the Tertiary Education Commission first makes this point:

The report goes on to talk about tertiary education in that context. That is precisely what the coalition was not saying as a government in 1976 to 1978. It rejected those arguments completely. In 1982 the rejection of those arguments is coming back to haunt it. The report also states:

Few unemployed and other disadvantaged young people are in their present circumstances by choice; at least in part they are there because of the decisions of other young people to whom a wider range of options is available.

What the report is talking about there is inequalities of opportunity in education. When honourable senators on the other side of the chamber say they are in favour of inequalities of opportunity in education they reflect the view which is expressed in this report about what is happening and what has happened in terms of funding for schools and access to post-secondary education. Let us look at the Government's record in relation to those matters. One of the reasons advanced in this report for declining access to post-secondary education is not only doubts about the function of post-secondary education in contemporary years but also the availability of student assistance schemes which encourage, in this report's view, education participation and a real decline in the value of student assistance schemes. The report goes on to make other recommendations about why people are turning away from post-secondary education. Senator Baume made no reference in his speech to the constant complaints about the declining level of research in Australian universities. All these matters are an indictment of a government of seven years which, blinded by ideology in 1976, 1977 and 1978, went off on the wrong tangent in relation to the development of the education system in this country.

I refer very briefly to Australian Labor Party policy because I want Senator Martyr to have something to chew on and not to give us the benefit of views which he has obtained elsewhere about what the ALP policy is in relation to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: -This debate on this matter of public importance is a weak faint attempt by the Opposition to raise some criticism of the Commonwealth Government's sound education record. The debate has fallen flatter than any matter of public importance this year. The Opposition is already beaten on the question of education policy. The only distinctive thing it has to offer is a divisive sectarian desertion of resourceful non-government schools. For the rest, it is following the Government's lead. The speeches made by Opposition members today amount to empty rhetoric. Why does not the Opposition recognise that the greater part of its recently announced education policy is a follow the leader policy, stepping out in clear directions already determined by the Liberal-National Party Government? Let me make it clear: What we should be talking about is the overwhelming commitment by the Commonwealth Government to education in Australia, a total Commonwealth commitment to education to the tune of $3.8 billion; that is, almost $4 billion a year. In money terms, it is almost exactly double what was spent by the Labor Government in 1975-76, which was only $1.894 billion. What we are talking about is a Commonwealth commitment to education of 8.1 per cent of this year's Budget, a Commonwealth commitment to education that is second only to social security and defence in terms of Budget outlays, a Commonwealth commitment that, as a nation, when the combined resources of Commonwealth and State are considered, totals over $7 billion in terms of public expenditure. The Opposition did not refer to that perspective but rather made snide, rhetorical remarks around the edges.

SPEECH.PARA: As a nation we spend more than $20m a day, every day of the year, on the education of our children. The education of all Australians is at stake. It is not a time to revive old bitternesses. It is not a time for opportunism or for half-considered promises; it is a time for sound policies. This divisiveness was never helpful. What we need now is communication between the parties, between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. What we need now and what we are offered by the Government are sound, well-considered policies. We need forward thinking; we need sensitivity to the needs of our century rather than a return to the unproductive, factional and sectional debate of the past. My colleague Senator Martyr will be acknowledging that there are many areas of agreement between our policies and the 'me too' policies of the Opposition as they have followed the Government's lead. These are the areas we should be concentrating on. These are the issues we should be addressing and in my remarks I will refer directly to specific education programs and education issues.

The contemporary needs of Australians are wide ranging and varied. That is a truism but it is directly to be borne in mind in all of these matters. Our education system aims to ensure that we have the flexibility to adapt to the needs and to address the problems that challenge us. Education is one response to the many needs of youth. Education must endeavour to meet the demands from schools that are relevant in an increasingly technological age, but education must, with even more priority, address itself to the mastery by school children of basic skills.

In the schools area, Commonwealth programs, which will amount to $1.24 billion in 1983, have two broad aims. Firstly, the provision of resources to achieve acceptable resource standards in all schools-in government schools and non- government schools-and to translate these into improved educational outcomes. Combined Commonwealth and State effort has improved recurrent resource standards in government schools by about 50 per cent in real terms since 1974. Standards in non-government schools have also increased in real terms, but only by almost 35 per cent since 1974. That is why the Government will not let down non- government schools, as the Opposition has suggested and put out in its policy. The Commonwealth policy is to provide a basic grant for all students attending government and non-government schools, with supplementary grants to students attending those schools that are assessed as being in greater resource need, and 80 per cent of non-government schools are seen to be 30 per cent below the average level in government schools. Why should a Liberal Government that believes in equality of opportunity deny resources to the non-government schools that are so far behind in resource allocation? We will not let down non- government schools and I believe that the introduction of this divisive policy by the Opposition is not helping in any respect.

Let me refer to one statistic in particular with regard to pupil-teacher ratios . In 1973 the overall ratio was 21.8 students per teacher for all systems, for all schools. But eight years later, by 1980, the ratio had fallen to 16.9 pupils per teacher. Throughout this period the pupil-teacher ratio for both government primary and secondary schools has remained consistently and substantially more favourable than for non-government schools. The first goal of our schools policy is to ensure that there in an acceptable resource standard and allocation among schools in Australia. The second broad goal is the provision of support for groups with special educational needs. I quote from page 1 of the most recent Commonwealth Schools Commission report, which states:

The Commission wishes to record its satisfaction that, in a difficult budgetary climate, the Government has accepted most of its recommendations on the funding of Commonwealth programs for schools in 1983. Especially important are the decisions to increase general recurrent funds for government schools and low- resource non-government schools, to provide additional resources for severely handicapped children and newly arrived migrant children and to give handicapped children of pre-school age access to the special education programs.

Apart from the migrant and multicultural education programs, the Commonwealth Government provides funds for the disadvantaged schools programs, which will receive $35m in 1983. The special education programs will receive $33m in 1983, which represents a real increase of 66 per cent since 1973. We have sought the integration of handicapped children into regular schools for their social and educational advantage. We have provided special programs for children for whom it is wise to remain in institutions. An amount of $3.6m will be allocated for that in 1983, which represents a real increase. The country areas program will receive $10m in 1983. This program was introduced by this Government in 1977 to provide support for students in isolated areas.

In the brief time that is available to me I will not have the opportunity to go over statements that I have made previously in the Senate with regard to the primary importance in schools of basic skills, of ensuring that what have been simply and, I think, erroneously called the three Rs-literacy, numeracy and the basic skills of comprehension, communication and analysis-are available to all children and that there is ability through the programs for mastery. This in turn requires us as a government to be committed to ensuring that teachers in training colleges are trained and not just academically educated. We have to ensure that teachers have the ability to train children in basic skills. We still need to press on with the restructuring of secondary education to ensure that the 25 per cent who comprise the most disadvantaged and underachieving students in Australia are not shunted into an academic stream that is geared to the Higher School Certificate or matriculation, but rather are given real self- confidence and motivation according to their vocational choice and vocational outcomes. We need to co-ordinate and enhance the language resource of Australia. That matter is the subject of a direct inquiry of a Senate standing committee to which the Government will be, I know, very responsive. We should not lose sight of important contemporary needs, such as mathematics training for girls. It is still a national scandal that the girls of Australia do not participate equally in mathematics training in education. Specific initiatives in curriculum are being supported by the Commonwealth to overcome that problem, but they are designed largely to turn around social and peer group attitudes.

With regard to isolated children, the Commonwealth Government received this year a report which it commissioned about evaluating and upgrading these schemes of assistance to children in the outback areas of Australia. The Government's response in the Budget directly followed advice that was given in the Tannock- Tomlinson report. With regard to Aboriginal studies curriculum, there has been an historic and tragic inability to offer Aboriginal languages and developed curriculum in Aboriginal studies in our schools. This has been addressed by the Commonwealth Government. The Commonwealth Aboriginal Studies Working Group report of March this year to the Australian Education Council was developed in its earlier stages by Commonwealth instrumentalities and representatives, not least the National Aboriginal Education Committee. The Commonwealth Government now seeks to address itself to the practical implementation of the pilot schemes that have been so carefully and well outlined in that report. I could refer to computer assisted learning and the advantages that that may have in terms of the contemporary needs of Australian school students. Let us not fall into the trap though of earlier years of thinking that the availability of television to students will solve everything. Some new technology for students will not solve everything. The best thing is still to have a well-motivated, warm-hearted, knowledgeable trained teacher encouraging students, but technology can be of some assistance.

The Commonwealth has directly faced these issues. Where it has direct responsibility, such as in the Australian Capital Territory, it has responded with initiatives-for example, the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts regarding preparation for the work force. In Canberra the secondary college system has proved a real success in that direction. The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has already referred to Program Youth, which is seeking to make sure that the educational initiatives for young people are in line with the recommendations of that report. The bilingual programs in Australian Capital Territory schools are still pacesetters. Today, with some other senators, I visited the North Ainslie school, which has a Greek bilingual program. This program has been of very real significance and success. Programs of this type need further encouragement not only in Canberra but also in the States. The recent Australian Labor Party policy speech addressed these points in a faint following of the Government's declared directions. There is a me tooism about the ALP's policy, which is to say that the perception of these issues by the Government is the one that the ALP would want to have too and it would like to commit itself to seeing these policies coming forward. The only distinctive part of the ALP's policy is the sectional and divisive stand against resourceful non-government schools. We stand against that. We will fight that. We believe that there ought to be an ability for family choice. We will not see a cutting back in the resources that are going fairly and equitably, according to the level of resource, to non-government schools.

If there had been time I would have spoken about transitional education and all the many initiatives that have been taken in regard to higher education. I have not had time to touch upon areas such as the centres of excellence program, the response to management education in Australia, the response to the Galbally report, and its implementation, and so on. This Government's achievements in education have been the pacesetter not only for debate in this Parliament but also for the States. I believe the Opposition's faint raising of this debate has fallen completely flat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating a matter of public importance on the failure of the Government to pursue education policies which meet contemporary needs. The debate has limited itself by and large to the issue of schools, so I will pursue that line and leave aside the other issues which, naturally enough, fall under the rubric that we are discussing. The unfortunate thing about the debate is that we have spent a lot of time here today discussing what is spent rather than how it is spent. Surely the issue is that massive education budgets can very well be misspent as spent well. It is the issue of how money is spent in education which presumably should exercise our minds, particularly if we are trying to meet contemporary needs. I have said on a number of occassions that I do not believe that this Government has a national education policy. I do not believe we have really sought in the 80-odd years of federation to disentangle the correct approach in terms of the responsibilities of the States within the federation and the responsibility of the Commonwealth within the federation. That is not necessarily a criticism of where we are, but that is undoubtedly the situation we are in.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to meet contemporary needs we have to disentangle very rapidly the responsibilities at the various levels and see who is responsible and who ought to be pursuing particular policies to meet those needs. Undoubtedly education requires, at the national level, a national perspective. We need to be able to integrate our education into our other policies, particularly into our economic policy but also into our social, cultural and other developmental policies. To have education policy by itself, sitting aside from all other policies, is to have an education policy that is of very little use. It must be linked with other policies, it must run parallel with them and, indeed, I believe that it must infuse them in order to to give direction.

Now, more than ever, we will fail unless we grasp that problem. We will fail because the contemporary needs of education are, in a peculiar way, our future needs. Education is one of the professions which seeks to look always to the future, and it must seek to look towards the future of this country if we are to have a successful education policy. When we implement an education policy we are saying to four or five year olds, or their parents, that when children go into our educational institutions we are seeking to assist them over the next 12 to 20-odd years and to form them in such a way that they will be productive and useful members of the community and will work towards their own betterment and the betterment of all others in society. But that means that we are saying to a person who goes into a pre-school today that he will be doing that after the year 2000. That is the point that we have to come to grips with and that, in a peculiar way, is the contemporary need because we know in this country that by the end of this decade over a third of our population will be in jobs they are not currently in. If that does not give us reason to pause then surely nothing else will.

We are meeting unprecedented rates of change and yet we tend, as we have done again today, to talk about more of the same. More of the same at this time will not assist us one iota. It would have done in the 1950s and it would have done in some way in the 1960s. It lost credibility rapidly in the 1970s and in the 1980s it is very much a recipe for disaster. Before the year 2000-that is, before those children now going into pre-school have finished their education- over four million young Australians will have gone on to the job market. Four million more young Australians will have been looking for work, looking to be productive. That is the type of thing we are talking about. We are not talking about a dollar here or a dollar there; we are talking about the very lifeblood, the very basis of our community and our society.

In our debates on education we have tended to talk about how much money should go to this school and how much should go to that school. Today the Government has been critical of the Australian Labor Party in terms of the points that the Labor Party has made about its policy on aid to non-government schools. I have said before, and I say again, that that argument was started by the Government. Unfortunately the Labor Party may have fallen into it, but certainly it was started by the Government. Australians have had this debate up to their necks, and we do not need it again. This country does not need to have yet another divisive, drag-out brawl about money going to government or non-government schools. Once and for all we have to accept that we have parallel systems within this country and we have to accept the doubtless economic imperative that before the end of this century almost every school in this country will be funded 100 per cent from government funds. That is an undoubted economic imperative when one looks at the costs.

We have to try to develop policies which will accommodate that fact within a democratic structure. We ought to stop talking about the whole issue of funds in relation to government and non-government schools and, rather, talk about how we can move both systems ahead so that both are better. I wish now to point to failings in both systems. Within the government structure, the failure is not, as the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) seemed to suggest, within the teachers. The failure within the government system is that it does not offer as wide a choice as is possible within the structure. The failure within the non -government system is that it offers a range of choice only to a small group of people.

The Australian Democrats stand very firmly for the notion that we should offer to all parents a choice in education. What we mean by that is not only a religious choice but also an educational choice. In other words, if a parent wishes to choose a particular school because it has a multicultural flavour, because it teaches languages in great depth and with great expertise, because it deals with computer education in a realistic and far-reaching way, because it takes maths seriously or because it knows that we are in a scientific age, that parent ought to have that choice. That, we believe, is to offer a real choice to the parents of Australia which will have effect into the next century. It is not to say to them that when we talk about choice we are talking about whether or not their children will receive a secular education or a religious-based education. That is a very small area of choice and to my way of thinking it is something from which we should have passed on. It is no longer a debate about whether we will have that particular range of choice in the community; the community has accepted that we will. What the community is not being offered is a range of choice in those other educational matters. That is where we must now put all of our energy and all of our innovative imagination and expertise, and we must do it together.

This Government has had a number of policies such as the attempted abolition of the Curriculum Development Centre or its consignment to some type of legislative limbo. We have had a serious diminution in the usefulness of the Schools Commission and we have had in the past-thank goodness it has now passed and I do not expect the present Minister to indulge in it-an attempt to shift responsibility for unemployment on to the schools. The States have been bludgeoned into reallocating funds from areas of high need into transition programs. All of those things have confused in many ways the responsibilities of the Commonwealth and the responsibilities of the States.

If we look at that issue in terms of where the responsibilities lie, undoubtedly they lie with the Commonwealth to explain or to articulate a program of funding in relation to what it sees as the imperatives of the next 20 years. The Commonwealth Government has that Commonwealth responsibility. It is a unique responsibility. It must spell out where it sees those extra four million young Australians being employed and what skills it believes they ought to have to be able to gain useful employment. In many ways that employment will be in jobs which certainly do not exist today. They are jobs which we, as a nation, must create. They will not just happen; we will have to develop them. The Government should seek as far as it is able to look ahead into those areas, to spell out for both government and non-government schools its visions and priorities and then make allowances for them. I hope at some stage within the next couple of weeks to speak in detail on the problem in Australia concerning mathematics. I say in passing that that is probably one area where Australia is failing badly.

When we look at the type of schooling system we want I think the Commonwealth Government has an obligation to say to the State government: 'You ought to be looking at bringing the community more into your schools and offering wider choices and greater diversity'. It ought to be saying to the non-government schools: 'Since you are moving to a position where you will be totally funded from public funds it is no longer possible for you to have exclusive control over who goes into your schools or who are jettisoned from your schools and how they are jettisoned from your schools'. In other words, the Commonwealth Government has to bite the bullet and say: 'If your schools are dependent on public funds they must meet public criteria. They must offer a service which is available to everybody within the community'. Many parents with children in Catholic schools may find that very difficult to accept. I say to them that they should look at what has occurred in countries overseas. For example, in some countries, such as Great Britain, Catholic schools are funded 100 per cent by the State. When Britain moved to that position the actual composition of Catholic schools did not change very much. By and large Protestants were not willing to send or interested in sending their children to Catholic schools unless they were seeking, as they are now, a particular type of education offered by them. If parents wish to do that it is a parental right. But as we move on into this century I do not see how schools that are supported from the public purse can keep those types of privileged entrances and exits.

I have discussed this matter with a wide range of people involved in those schools. I think they see the equity and the justice of those ideas. They do not in any way seek to take from parents their choice, the right to have public funds for their schools or the range of schools which is offered. They are seeking to broaden that range of choice to include all parents within this community who seek not only a religious education for their children but also a particular type of education.

I think the Government also has a responsibility to say to private schools: ' There are other areas at which you ought to look'. Unfortunately, I think the debate to date has not done anything other than re-arrange deck chairs on the Titanic when we ought to be attempting to establish life boats to the future for this country. Surely that is what we are about. We must assist each other in the development of that precious resource-those children who are put into our care. They are put into the care of a variety of people in this country. Our concerns are identical. We want children to flourish and develop their best talents so that together everybody in this country will be able to provide for people in the future a better country than we have at present. That really is the aim of any education system. It cannot be achieved by ripping ourselves apart yet again in this country on the divisive issue of where the dollar goes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martyr Sen J.R.

But the actual terms of the matter of public importance brought forward by the Opposition make it very much like some of the debates that we have had in previous weeks. The whole objective of the debate today is to score political points. An even more serious charge I make is that the debate today also creates division once again on what we used to call state aid.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that members of the Opposition have suggested that only they understand contemporary education needs and how those needs may be truly satisfied. That is laughable. By what particular miracle did the Opposition, thrashed at three previous elections because it could not or would not come to terms with this problem or relate to the average Australian, suddenly acquire an expertise which has eluded it for years? The truth is that it has not acquired any such expertise. In real terms the Government's expenditure is equal to the essential demand. Figures are available in the Basic Paper No. 15 put out by the Parliamentary Library to which I will refer later. Curricula construction and implementation is fundamentally the work of state governments. They are now facing up to the enormous problems that exist today and the realities of education and training in difficult circumstances. They have not always done that. Of course this trend will continue to be consistent in the future and it will answer the real needs of education. A government of our persuasion has been in office between 1949 and 1972 and 1975 and 1982. It is our kind of government which broke the log-jam of injustice to private schools. It seems to me that the only real problem of injustice that still remains in the education system is that parity of funding between government and private schools has not yet been achieved. I hope that in my lifetime I will see this achieved. I know that the only possibility of seeing the parity of funding between government and private systems is by the retention of this government. Any other kind of government-the Government that we saw here between 1972 and 1975-will be no guarantee to me or to anybody else who supports the private system. People have the right to choose the kind of education they want and to get a fair share of the funds they put in . There will be no guarantee for me or for any of those people if there is a Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the difficulties about the policies of the Australian Labor Party is that there are obviously several policies. Today we have had the Ryan policy and the Button policy. A day or two ago we had the Dawkins policy. We have had the Hayden policy and the Federal Conference policy. All those policies are marginally different. It seems to me that the margin of difference is in the audiences that various spokespeople for the Labor party are addressing. I have at least two interpretations of the five policies that I have heard about. The two worst versions are mutually exclusive. Labor senators hope, when they address audiences consisting mainly of people who support the organisation known as DOGS, the Council for the Defence of Government Schools, that what they say is private and does not get into the Press. There is always trouble when there are quotations by Labor speakers who go to meetings such as this. It seems to me that honourable senators have assured DOGS supporters that the government schools will be favoured and that Labor's long policy term is to encourage only one form of education; that is the government form of education.

With audiences of private schools honourable senators seldom speak about parity and they say something quite different to what they say to the DOGS audiences. They suggest-there are some who are naive enough to believe it-that Labor is totally dedicated to preserving and protecting the private education system. As I say, this is for general private school audiences only. When they go round to speak to people who come from poorer parish schools, the line is varied just a little. This is to indicate that Labor will look after them and will cut down or cut out the funding to larger and relatively more prosperous private schools. Plainly the two major lines of Labor's policy are mutually exclusive and plainly divisive in their intent. The essence of Labor's line to the smaller and larger private schools is also deliberately divisive in trying to set one against the other. I want members of the Opposition to know that we are awake to their divisive tactics. We will be expressing everything we know about these divisive tactics in education debates from now on.

I want to tell the Senate about a document entitled 'The Discrimination Gap in Public Expenditure on Government and Non-Government Schooling 1980-81'. The source of the figures is the Commonwealth Department of Education in March 1982. Of the total Australian schooling budget for 1980-81, 88 per cent is spent on government school children and 12 per cent is spent on non-government school children. Honourable senators will know that 76.9 per cent of Australian school children are in government schools and that 23.1 per cent are non-government school children. A total of 94.8 per cent of State government expenditure goes to government schools and only 5.2 per cent goes to non-government schools. The relationship is much closer with the Commonwealth. Senator Peter Baume has been trying to demonstrate this today. It seems to have fallen on deaf ears in the Labor Party. A total of 52.6 per cent of Commonwealth Government expenditure is spent on government schools and 43.8 per cent of Commonwealth Government expenditure is spent on non-government schools.

It is quite plain that there is a long way to go before there is reasonable parity. This problem which has bedevilled us in the Senate and members in the House of Representatives for so long has been in existence too long. We have to get to parity as quickly as we can. I will be content if parity is achieved in my lifetime. I know that if there is a Labor government I may not live long enough to see this parity come into being. This does not just occur to me, or to people who may have a definite ideological bent for private schools. It has also occurred to the editors of the Canberra Times. The editorial of Friday 19 November stated:
On the basis of the aggregate figures--
These are the figures I have quoted-
Anyway, it is apparent that parents of children in non-government schools are subsidising parents with children in government schools.

That is a very strong and truthful statement for the editors of the Canberra Times to make. Finally, the Government's record on education is very sound. The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has clearly indicated the high points of what the Government is doing in education. He has been well backed up by Senator Teague. We, on the Government side, have no case to answer. For Senator Button to come in here and suggest that it would be my job to demolish the Labor Party's case in this debate is one of the silliest assertions I have heard him make in a number of silly assertions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious you are incompetent to demolish anything.

—Senator Evans is in the chamber. He has woken up. There is nothing to demolish. Perhaps if Senator Evans were leading in the debate for the Labor Party we would have heard something which was worth answering. But today we have heard nothing at all that is worth answering. All I can say-honourable senators heard what Senator Peter Baume and Senator Teague had to say about the Government's record-is that, summed up, it is sound, fair and understanding. On the other hand, members of the Labor Party are absolutely bankrupt on this particular subject as they are on almost all others. They have wasted the time of the Senate. Without further ado, I move:
