TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to vote against the second reading of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill and associated legislation. I will support the foreshadowed amendments in the Committee stage, if the second reading is carried, of which contingent notice of motion has been given. I have four reasons why I am opposed to the passage of the Bill at the second reading. The first is that I believe it is wrong philisophically because it indulges in retrospectivity. I do not intend to attempt to give the Senate a lecture on retrospectivity-that matter has been canvassed here for a number of days-but I think one ought to be grateful that at last the Government has recognised that the legislation is in fact retrospective. For a long time we had the quaint idea promoted by the Government that what was involved was merely a recoupment; it was not retrospective. The Government dressed it up with all sorts of semantics. I do not think that did the Government's credibility much good at all. I think it was forced into the position illustrated by these words which George Orwell wrote back in 1946:

SPEECH.PARA: Political languge-and with variations this is true of all political parties, from Conservatives to Anarchists-is designed to make lies sound truthful and murder respectable, and to give an appearance of solidity to pure wind.

I am afraid that is what the Government's propaganda about this measure was for a very long time. The only other comment I wish to make about retrospectivity is that there have been some allegations from my political opponents that somehow or other Perth is the tax evasion capital of Australia and that it is full of somewhat dubious Liberal lawyers who were doing odd things within their professions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name one.

—Of course, nobody has yet named one, but it is rather interesting that my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned the other night that the infamous Mr Bercove was one of the Labor lawyers for liberty, or something like that. He is perhaps the most notorious of all the lawyers caught so far. I shall read from a Queen's Counsel's opinion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I refer to the stated justification for the proposed legislation: the Government has 'decided on this course of action because of the essentially fraudulent nature of much of the conduct involved'. The first point to be made is that nothing in the press release indicates that a distinction will be drawn between vendor shareholders who acted fraudulently, or were aware of the fraudulent intention of others, and those who did not. Of course the legislation will say nothing of the sort. A characteristic of the members of the class in question will be their lack of knowledge of that which entrepreneurs or purchasers would do. It adds nothing to the rational discussion of matters such as this to use emotive phraseology such as 'essentially fraudulent', however attractive that may be as political rhetoric.

Secondly, it may be granted that some involved in such transactions acted in a truly fraudulent manner. Their sins are to be visited upon the vendor shareholders, who were legally entitled to act as they did when the actions were performed, and who are to be deprived of the benefits of limited liability and made liable for the taxation liability which was not at inception or subsequently theirs. All who care about the rule of law should feel outraged by such a proposal.

That opinion is dated 19 August 1982 in Perth and is given by one Ian D. Temby Q .C. who, some six or nine months ago, was the endorsed candidate of the Australian Labor Party in the by-election in the electorate of Nedlands, caused by the retirement of Sir Charles Court. I think that ought to be put on the record as the opinion of someone who might be said to be one of my political opponents.

I move now to my second reason for opposing this legislation: I think it is politically stupid. It is quite wrong because all it has done initially is to encourage Mr Wran in his essay on retrospective stamp duties which blew up in his face and which he had to give away in the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —He went back to 1962.

—Yes. He went back to 1920, he said inadvertently; once something hit the fan he could not duck away from it fast enough. I have no doubt that the initial intention was to go back to 1920. It has also encouraged the Australian Labor Party. Senator Evans was recently reported in the Press-I trust, accurately-on how the Labor Party, if it got to office, would conduct its war retrospectivity against tax evasion and avoidance. I am quite certain that the ALP would not have adopted retrospectivity with such fervour if members on this side of the Parliament had not made retrospectivity respectable. That is why I refer to the political stupidity of this legislation. I can never see any point in a political party making the bad policies of its opponents respectable. That is all we are doing by this legislation. In logic, if the Government believes in retrospectivity in respect of the present Bills, why should it not then recoup all that tax from dry Slutzkin schemes, from Curran schemes, from family trusts and from family partnerships? There is no reason why it should not because so far nobody has said that everybody in the present scheme had been fraudulent. The vendor-shareholders were not fraudulent; they were merely tax avoiders at that stage. But why, in logic, should we catch those engaged in a wet Slutzkin and not a dry Slutzkin? Once we go down this slipperty track of wet Slutzkins we end up in all sorts of other things. The Government's argument about fairness and equity lends weight to the Labor Party's point of view that we should legislate retrospectivity to catch all tax avoidance schemes which have been around, say, post the mid-1960s.
—That is not what we said; of a blatant, contrived and artificial kind.
—There is no reason why it should not.
—Come on! Don't be dishonest. You are doing very well.
—There is no reason, once the Government accepts retrospectivity for this set of offences, why it should ever oppose retrospectivity for any other sort of tax avoidance scheme.
—Which is of a blatant, contrived or artificial kind.
—It depends on what is blatant, contrived or artificial. There is no judicial determination of that matter. It is a matter of what is in one's mind.
—Fairness is a subjective view.

—Yes. Everything is subjective, be it love, beauty or even tax fairness, I suppose. If we are to recoup some tax why should we not recoup all sorts of tax? For those reasons I think it is a foolish decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The third reason I am opposed to the legislation is because I believe it to be unnecessary. No evidence has ever been produced that the present legislation is ineffective to catch the fraudulent evaders-those who ought to be caught under the Crimes Act, the Companies Act or the presently existing taxation Acts. I put it quite strongly to the Senate that the only reason this legislation is necessary is to cover up bureaucratic bungling, incompetence and lethargy, because the schemes should have been stopped back in 1975. If anybody in this country should be given a medal it is Mr Todman who discovered these schemes in 1972, according to the Costigan report. He did a vast amount of work on these matters until the time of the Brinsden opinion in mid-1975. It is rather interesting that Mr Todman seems to have disappeared. I imagine he has now retired. He ought to be publicly thanked for first exposing and getting on to these matters. The 1975 law was adequate, according to Brinsden, Lockhart and others. Everybody knows about those opinions.

Who was to blame? I initially thought the Commisisoner of Taxation ought to get a cuff under the ear because he had not been sufficiently diligent, but having looked at the telephone book of documents which was tabled, it is quite obvious that he nagged year in and year out like an aching tooth. I almost said 'mother- in-law' but that would not be appropriate with the present Acting Deputy President in the chair. The Commissioner nagged away trying to get some action but nothing happened. Admittedly, perhaps he should have nagged the Attorney- General's Department harder and harder. I suspect that what happened was that he was so used to rotten service from the Attorney-General's Department that he thought the rotten service he was getting was normal service. One can get so used to bad service that one thinks it is normal and it does not worry one. He thought that the inaction was par for the course for that Department. I think the real blame belongs to both Harders and Neaves. These two cannot escape responsibility. In a private practice they would not only have been sued for negligence but also reported to their professional organisations and, most likely, struck off the register. There is no way any private legal firm could leave a client's business file in a bottom drawer for seven years and escape either a negligence action or being struck off by the professional group or the Full Bench of a Supreme Court.

What has happened here? A couple of minnows in Perth are chased. Poor Bercove, as if it was all his fault. Fancy the head of one of the major legal firms in Australia-be it Malleson's, Blake's or Allen's-saying: 'It was not my fault. I gave it to the articled clerk and he forgot about it'. Imagine getting away with that! Anybody who knows anything about anything knows that one just cannot blame the office boy for one's own dereliction of duty. Harders and Neaves had the job and they got the money. They pleaded before the Remuneration Tribunal that they ought to get more money because of the responsibility that they carry. Permanent heads argue for a bigger responsibility allowance. When something goes wrong it is said: 'Yes, but that is somebody else's fault; it is the bloke out in the branch office'.

I believe that both Harders and Neaves ought to be sacked. If they are not sacked at least they ought to be immortalised somehow or other in limericks or clerihews. I have had a go but the result is not terribly good. There are many more erudite people in this place who have a far better sense of rhythm than I have and I would be grateful if they would polish it up. I would start off with something like this:
A negligent lawyer named Harders,
Had a head as empty as Mother Hubbard's larders.
Because he was so lax
The Commissioner received no tax,
And the companies went to the bottom of the harbours.
Of Mr Neaves, one could say:
A foolish lawyer names Neaves,
Was so negligent he encouraged tax thieves.
Because he was so lax,
The Act on income tax
Now has another 80 leaves.

These fellows should not be allowed to go scot-free. I am not prepared to support legislation made retrospective 10 years to catch taxpayers-I have been quite open in public on this-when public servants go scot-free.

We hear a lot these days, quite properly, about law reform. One of the things which law reform commissions have been bending their minds to in recent years is how to smarten up the private legal sector. A number of suggestions have been made. It is said that lawyers should not try each other in club; they should not do it in secret. There should be consumers' representatives to see that the general public is being given a fair go. By and large the legal profession agrees with all these very necessary reforms. What is good enough for the private sector ought to be good enough for the public sector. Who can take some action against two negligent lawyers running a big legal practice who have cost their client-the Commissioner of Taxation-$450m, $500m? I do not know what the figure is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Six hundred million.

—Perhaps $600m. It would be the biggest negligence action in this country. If I were the Commissioner of Taxation I would be taking acting against them if I could. The fourth reason I oppose this legislation is that it is all about what one might call the game law mentality. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would know that the game laws of the United Kingdom perhaps had their origin with those well known Norman kings. If one took one of their deer in one of their forests one lost one's hand or one's eye. As the centuries rolled by the game laws got tougher and tougher. I suppose one could say thank goodness for that, otherwise many of the people transported to Australia for poaching would not have been sent here. But in the late eighteenth century the situation became so extreme that there were some 200 or 300 offences for which a person could be hanged or transported for life. This legislation is following a similar course. We are trying to get more gamekeepers and to make the poaching laws harsher; we are taking no action to do away with what causes people to poach. Most people who take any interest in the criminal law or criminology would agree with Mr Clifford, the Director of the Australian Institute of Criminology. He was reported recently, when talking about some necessary reforms in the criminal law and our attitude on law breaking, as saying that the answer is not harsher penalties and more police. He was not talking about tax. That is what these Bills are all about. They are all part of the game law syndrome.

SPEECH.PARA: We in this place take a rather superior attitude, do we not, about Pakistan, Iran and the savage punishments that they mete out for what we would regard as quite minor offences. But I say that we are going down the same track. One of the interesting things about this debate is that in spite of all the hyperbole we have heard about fairness, equity and getting back allegedly stolen money-all the pure wind people are attempting to roll into solidity-what comes through more than anything is a feeling of vengeance. That is what honourable senators want. They want revenge on the people who they think stole their tax revenue. Honourable senators want the same sort of vengeance wreaked on those people as they want wreaked on a criminal or anybody else who offends them. That is what I call the game law mentality.

What is going to happen? I can predict it. We are going to have a bigger tax Act; we are going to have more and more laws, more and more tax officials, more and more people prosecuted, more and more people bankrupted and more evasion and more avoidance. It is absolutely predictable. I could understand the Tories getting together on the game law attitude. The English gentry were fully in favour of enforcing the game laws. I suppose there are some landed proprietors in Australia who believe that they are the direct descendants of them. I can understand the socialists believing in game laws concerning tax because they are a party of materialism. Of course they are materialists. We keep saying, do we not, that they are socialists, materialists, not people of the spirit. Why people who really regard themselves as liberals could get picked up with the game law attitude totally escapes me.

The Tories, the anarchists, the socialists, the revolting peasants-call them what one likes-have all joined forces to enforce a new set of game laws and they are going to be very proud of it. That is why I will not support this legislation. Nobody is terribly interested about individual rights, human rights and the rule of law. Nobody wants to talk about that. This legislation represents a triumph of materialism over liberalism. Money is the most important thing that we can think of. That is what we want-money. It does not matter by what means we get it or how we use it. As long as we get that $400m, $500m, $ 600m, or $700m it does not matter what happens; we want the money. I would not have thought that that is the way we should do it. Because I believe this legislation represents a triumph of materialism over real liberalism there must be a division at the second reading stage of the debate. I think that the socialists, the Tories and the materialists all ought to sit together, be seen to be sitting together and be counted so that they can all be exposed for what they are.

As I said the penalties will get harsher, retrospectivity will grow and the rule of law will continue to be trampled on. The cash economy is alive and well. It is thriving and it will get bigger and the end result, of course, is that we will get worse laws and end up with probably less revenue from a distorted section of the taxpayers. A few harmless lunatics-as they may be considered-talk about flat rate tax. That may not necessarily be the answer but at least they are talking about some sort of tax reform. There are those who disappear into the distance and talk about a different mix between direct and indirect tax but they are still not really getting to the fundamental problems of taxation in this country. The real problem of taxation in this country, of course, is that all governments which wish to buy votes at election times and raise expectations which they will never realise keep using a revenue gathering Act for expenditure purposes.

I reckon that I could write a tax Act in about 10 pages and get rid of most of the avoiders; I would not get rid of the evaders. We will always have the crooks in this business. We will always have people who will understate their incomes. We will not do away with evasion even if we start cutting their hands off. People have suffered all sorts of physical and financial hurt in their attempts to cheat the tax gatherer. They will keep on doing it. But we would get rid of most of the tax avoidance in Australia if Parliament-it is our fault the present situation exists-did not keep legislating to invent new schemes whereby tax avoiders could make a welter out of what were thought to be good political ideas . I mention but the film industry and art collections tax schemes.

For some 40 years now-most likely for some 50 years-the whole of the Income Tax Assessment Act has been becoming more and more distorted as governments give more and more concessions by way of amendments to the tax Act. If political parties would bend their minds to having very simple revenue raising legislation , if they would hand out all the goodies they wished to hand out by using the expenditure side of the Budget, through the Appropriation Bills-be they general or special-that would provide some idea of what they were spending and some idea of who was collecting it. Then most of the tax avoidance in this country would go. Who is not in tax avoidance? On the front page of the Australian this morning a gentleman from the Australian Conservation Foundation was reported as seeing nothing wrong at all in getting donations, laundering them through his own organisation as tax free money, taking 2 per cent off the top, then passing the money on to somebody else. Everybody talks about lack of morality in this country, yet everybody is in it. Tax concessions generally are opposed by the revenue gatherers. Quite clearly, the Commissioner of Taxation knows that whenever politicians get those crazy notions about giving a special benefit to a particular class of person it will be exploited and will become a rort. The politician brushes that fact aside because there will most likely be a vote in what he is doing to the Income Tax Assessment Act.

Until we get back to using the Income Tax Assessment Act to raise revenue and the Appropriation Bills to expend money we will stay in this tax mess. It is no use adopting the game law attitude. That will change nothing. It will make things worse. We will end up with a more divided society. We will not shift the burden of taxation by making the Act more and more complicated. With a complicated Act we will not stop either tax evasion or tax avoidance. We will have harsher penalties, more injustices and more discretions placed on the Commissioner of Taxation. I guarantee the bigger the Act grows, the harsher the penalties, the more the cash economy will thrive.

We have just seen the first signs of barter in this country. Honourable senators who have not seen such signs will know of others who have. Such trade will grow. I am really opposed to the legislation because of the game law mentality. This sort of thing will do nothing for taxation reform. It will satisfy the desire for vengeance of those who want to wreak their wrath on these so-called wicked, evil people. It may satisfy those who wish to gobble up this $ 400m, $500m or $600m. For those four reasons I intend to vote against the second reading of the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few remarks in relation to the taxation Bills, not to go over ground that has been already canvassed by a large number of honourable senators who have spoken during the debate, but to canvass what I believe to be a couple of relevant points relating to the retrospective legislation proposed by the Government. Senator Withers, who has just spoken, tried to make out that the Australian Labor Party was proposing this legislation. In actual fact this retrospective legislation has been brought into this place by the Government. It has been brought into this place by the Government only because of the Government's lack of action. We heard Senator Withers talk about officers within various departments, saying that they should be struck off the legal register because of their non-action. He said that if there was a clerk working for those gentlemen who did not carry out the duty they were supposed to, one could not blame the clerk; one had to look at the people who were in charge of the action being taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I go a bit further and say that the reason the Government has brought in the retrospective legislation and seeks to make changes to the Income Tax Assessment Act is the lack of action not just by the Government but, more specifically, by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). If we talk about fairness in relation to laying blame at people's feet, about people in charge in departments placing files at the bottom of a drawer and not doing anything about them for a number of years, about not being able to blame the clerk, I think it is very reasonable for us to say that the Treasurer should accept some blame for the problems that have occurred within the taxation system within Australia. We should also blame the Attorney-General for not taking action when those rorts were taking place, when the people of Australia were being robbed of tax that should have been paid, when the rorts were being worked . This is the time when the Treasurer and the Attorney-General were not taking positive action to upset the tax avoiders and the tax evaders in this country.

It was not any action of the Government that made it introduce retrospective legislation or take some action in relation to the Income Tax Assessment Act; it was the McCabe-Lafranchi report and the report of the Costigan Royal Commission of Inquiry on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. It was those reports that drew the attention of the public to tax avoidance and tax evasion and led them to ask that some action be taken in relation to it. The Government, in supporting the report of the Royal Commission of Inquiry on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, grabbed the thin edge of the wedge. It did not really believe that the Royal Commission's findings would go as far as they did and indicate the amount of tax evasion and avoidance that had been taking place in this country, the amount of tax evasion and avoidance that the Attorney-General and Treasurer had not taken any note of at the time it was taking place. I suppose that one should look at the amount of revenue that is being lost to the Australian people and the Australian Government and the extra burden that is being placed on the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer because no action has been taken by this Government when tax evasion and avoidance has been taking place and bottom- of-the-harbour schemes have been under way in this country. That scheme has spread at an amazing rate. The McCabe-Lafranchi report gave details of some 900 companies which were investigated, out of 3,000 companies which it was alleged were involved in all States. The Australian Taxation Office now admits that around 6,000 companies may have been involved. The New South Wales Government reportedly has a list of around 4,000 companies involved in that State. It is impossible to tell where the scheme stops.

It was because of that scheme, the problems that existed with taxation and the amount of revenue lost to the Department of the Treasury, that this Government decided to take some action and to bring in retrospective legislation in relation to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. I believe that was a correct action. It has been quite surprising to me that a number of honourable senators on the Government side have opposed retrospective legislation and have stood in this place and used a number of quotations from learned members of the law community to back up their arguments.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have always understood that.

The following table shows that large majorities of both Liberal-National Party and Australian Labor Party electors favor the law:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as an unashamed supporter of the Government's proposals that are before us and I trust that the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 and the other legislation before us will be endorsed by the Senate today without any amendment. I believe that we have before us legislation which demonstrates the Government's intention to collect moneys which should have been paid and made available by the taxpayers of Australia for necessary government purposes over the years, moneys which were denied by fraud and evasion and from which certain people have obtained benefits . Those people who have obtained benefits will be required to repay them so that the ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayer in this community shall not suffer. All the nonsense that has been talked in this place and elsewhere about retrospectivity overlooks the fact that, if anybody suffers because of the failure to go ahead with legislation of this sort, retrospectively the people to suffer will be the present day PAYE taxpayers who will pay more tax and not receive concessions because the bright boys have got away with the frauds which they perpetrated.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say various things about the general nature of this legislation. It is designed generally to catch bottom-of-the-harbour schemes; frauds which have been perpetrated. What is a bottom-of-the-harbour scheme? Put very simply, a company with current year profits is stripped of all its assets so it is left with no money. The company's ordinary tax liability-that is, company tax or the undistributed profit tax-is not paid. The company is sold to a promoter who pays an inflated price for it because he knows the tax liability will not be paid. The promoter in turn sells the company to people with fictitious names and bogus addresses. In other words the company was transferred to people who had no money and who could not be traced. The Commissioner of Taxation is then owed money from each such company under the existing taxation law, but the company has no funds to pay him. The company has vanished without paying its tax liability and it has no assets from which to satisfy the debt.

Bottom-of-the-harbour schemes are not clever devices for avoiding taxation; they are fraudulent exercises in tax evasion by which taxation, lawfully payable by a company on current year earnings, remains payable but unable to be collected. I believe that when one realises those plain facts one is amazed at the extent to which there has been opposition to this legislation. Some of the opposition is genuine and sincere, but I am afraid that some of my colleagues on this side of the chamber have been induced-they are mostly laymen-sometimes by clever lawyers, into believing that there is some enormous overriding principle that no legislation should be made retrospective. I will come to that question in a moment. We know that something like $580m was evaded by means of these schemes and the Government has said that that must be paid. When the Government shows its firmness and determines these things then I think we must recognise that its attitude is popular. I think reference has already been made to the most recent Morgan gallup poll about this matter. In that poll people were asked :
'Are you for or against that new retrospective law to . . . collect unpaid taxes from the shareholders of companies which 'went to the bottom of the harbour'?'

What was the reply? Sixty-five per cent of all people-the result is very similar with respect to party allegiances-were for the new law. Sixteen per cent voted against the new law and nineteen per cent were undecided. The same people were then asked:
'Apart from this particular case, are you for or against retrospective laws to help collect unpaid taxes?'
Those for retrospectivity, 60 per cent; those against, 22 per cent; and undecided, 18 per cent. So there is a very heavy public demand for the Government to take this action.

TALK.START.PARA: —But really that is irrelevant.
—It is not irrelevant at all. I regard that as very important. I would have thought that we were here as the servants of democracy. People have quoted other polls.
—Not by gallup poll. I am supporting this legislation, but not as a result of a gallup poll.

—I am not supporting it because of a gallup poll. There is a fair amount of popularity in my party for this legislation. I believe it is right and just. The fact that the public understands the need for it is an important consideration. It is important to realise also that, although the Government has made some concessions, the Bill has not been watered down. Despite the criticisms which have been made of it, the Taxpayers' Association Journal had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill hasn't been watered-down. The changes merely recognise that in many cases it would be impossible for the vendor shareholders to sell enough assets quickly enough to avoid crippling interest hitting them harder.

It is clear that before us we have a reasonably undiluted attempt by the Government to enforce these obligations. Much of the criticism that has come from colleagues on this side of the chamber has been on the basis that the Government was slow to appreciate the problem-the Government did not take action . Of course the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, and other reports, have indicated most incredible delays, misjudgments and bureacratic bunglings on the part of persons who ought to have known better. Nonetheless, that was no excuse for the Government, when it realised the position, not to proceed then with expedition and not to proceed as hard as it could.

I understand and respect the attitude of my colleague Senator Hill who takes a reasoned view of this matter and concludes, quite contrary to my view, that existing laws might be sufficient. I do not believe the existing laws would be sufficient to recover the moneys which otherwise would be lost, but at least he bases his argument on reason and not on the argument of others who unfortunately have been persuaded that the only principle of taxation is non-retrospectivity and not fairness and equity between one taxpayer and another.

The question of retrospectivity which has dominated this debate is one which I think should be faced. It is one by which non-lawyers are mesmerised. They think that, because something was legal when it was done, the legality of it must not be changed and the rights must not be altered. There have been all kinds of absurd propositions as to why we should not do this sort of thing. We in this Parliament approve retrospective legislation in the form of Bills time after time. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances approves retrospective provisions about twice a week. They are beneficial provisions. They are provisions which point out that the Government may be slow in awarding people payments.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's different, giving something, much different.

—The honourable senator does not mind that. There the difference lies. He says that one case is good retrospectivity and the other is bad retrospectivity. Why does he make that judgment? I happen to make a judgment that retrospectivity is much more justified than he judges it. Certainly in these cases there is a beneficial need for retrospectivity.
—Every time you change the company tax it is retrospective.

—Of course it is. We do it so many times. Senator Hamer and I well recall a debate at a meeting of the Liberal Party State Council in Melbourne last weekend when the Council threw out a proposal for some general bars against retrospectivity. There we heard the Honourable Alan Hunt, for many years the leader of the Upper House in Victoria and a conscientious Liberal at that, saying that he had supported more than 150 pieces of retrospective legislation with a clear conscience. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If anyone tells me it is not Liberal, or contrary to principle, I say we don't belong to the same party. It's nonsense to create an overall principle where none exists.

That was very well said by Alan Hunt and it is very true. Of course, as I have said, it takes one principle and there is an existing principle. The law generally tries to interpret against retrospectivity. It prefers, where there is doubt, to rule against a retrospective operation. We in this Parliament prefer to deal with something retrospectively only in the case of need. But where crooked people have got away with money for years and where we can deal with them only by using this sort of method, it must be used.

Let me remind people that in this case we are not using retrospectivity to create criminal offences. That is a slide which has been adopted by many of the people who argue in this area. They point to Article 15 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which states:

No one shall be held guilty of any criminal offence on account of any act or omission which did not constitute a criminal offence, under national or international law, at the time when it was committed. Nor shall a heavier penalty be imposed than the one that was applicable at the time when the criminal offence was committed. If, subsequent to the commission of the offence, provision is made by law for the imposition of a lighter penalty, the offender shall benefit thereby.

That is quite true, but we all agree that the Article relates to criminal penalties. Nobody doubts that it is undesirable to do that. But in the case of the recoupment of tax which ought to have been paid by individuals but which, because of a sleight of hand or illegalities, was not paid, a completely different situation prevails. It is an interesting fact that the power of parliaments to legislate retrospectively has been cited very often by judges. Reference probably has been made already in this debate to Lord Greene, who in dealing with this matter said, among other things:

It would not shock us in the least to find that the legislature has determined to put an end to the struggle by imposing the severest of penalties. It scarcely lies in the mouth of the taxpayer who plays with fire to complain of burnt fingers.
That is how he responded to people who were objecting to retrospective legislation. He went on to say:

The fact that the section has to some extent a retroactive effect again appears to us of no importance when it is realised that the legislation is a move in a long and fiercely contested battle with individuals who well understand the rigour of the contest.
Likewise, Viscount Simon, who was Lord Chancellor, in dealing with similar legislation, said:

Judicial dicta may be cited which point out that, however elaborate and artificial such methods may be, those who adopted them are ''entitled'' to do so . There is, of course, no doubt that they are within their legal rights, but that is no reason why their efforts, or those of the professional gentlemen who assist them in the matter, should be regarded as a commendable exercise of ingenuity or as a discharge of the duties of good citizenship. On the contrary, one result of such methods, if they succeed, is, of course, to increase pro tanto the load of tax on the shoulders of the great body of good citizens who do not desire, or do not know how, to adopt these manoeuvres.

That, I suggest, is the major principle. It is the principle of fairness which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) have amply demonstrated in this legislation. We do not want to see the burden imposed in this way on other citizens. We used retrospective legislation against the Curran scheme in 1978. We have used retrospective legislation on many occasions when it has been necessary. We know that here we are dealing with people who broke the existing law and who acted with greed. People who would be prepared to buy a watch outside a shop window knowing quite well that it was worth a lot more than they were paying for it run the risk of having to disgorge later on, and when they disgorge we should not be trying to protect them or defend them.

One of the main arguments against retrospectivity has always been that we must have certainty in the law. There is a feeling, a grasp, on the part of non- lawyers that certainty is a necessity, but much of the law has been built largely on retrospectivity. In the early days the common law recognised people's rights to land and to other things and if a person's possession was in his name he could do what he liked with it. Then along came the courts and subsequently the Parliament creating the law of equity which was superimposed on the common law and which changed the rights of people at common law. It said: 'You must recognise trusts, you must recognise beneficial interests by other persons in your land'. So people had their rights changed retrospectively. The whole greatness of the equity system created in Britain both by the courts and by the Parliament lies in the fact that it was created retrospectively. This was pointed out very well in a letter which Mr James Guest, an eminent lawyer in Victoria, wrote on this subject a short time ago. He said:

All people whose land, money or other assets are held in trust for their benefit from the long tradition in English law which has allowed the most solidly entrenched rules of the common law to be disregarded in favor of the requirements of ''good conscience and equity''. To own something at common law was not (and is not enough) if the equity jurisdiction of the King's court found that the way in which the common law owner acquired it made it unconscionable for him to hold it for his own benefit. Such was the origin of the trust; like the early remedies for fraud it was created retrospectively.

I think it is important for those who sob now against retrospectivity to bear this in mind. I can well imagine the reaction of my colleagues' equivalents in 1833 when the British House of Commons abolished slavery throughout the British Empire. They must have been very concerned about the retrospective destruction of rights which they had enjoyed for generations. They must have thought that they were entitled, because of the certainty of the law, to go on enjoying and flogging their slaves for the next 100 years, but that right was suddenly gone. I am afraid that I have heard in the arguments of some of my colleagues today the reflection of those slavers of 1833. Who will pay if we do not have retrospectivity? It is very clear that the victims will be the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. Those people these days are paying something like ten per cent more of the whole taxation of this country than ten years ago. In 1972 they were paying, as a percentage of income tax, 55.23 per cent. They are now paying 66.39 per cent. I think that is wrong. I have many other objections to the tax law. I draw attention to the great increase in PAYE taxpayer's obligations and to the lesser increase in company tax. It is a lesser increase because people using the cash economy put money in their own pockets. I think these matters must be taken into account. TALK.START.PARA: —I turn now to another question. Of course it has been said that this legislation seeks to recover moneys obtained by evasion. It does not, of course, deal with avoidance. There is considerable confusion about this subject. I, for one, have not a great deal of strong faith in the variation and difference between evasion and avoidance. In many respects, of course, I think that the elaborate schemes of tax avoidance which have been adopted in this country for some years and which have lost the government millions of dollars are worse than the petty evasions by people taking money out of their tills and not accounting for it when paying tax. I draw some comfort from the fact that, in 1980, the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act outlawed both evasion and avoidance in relation to the Slutzkin schemes. I am glad to see that, in future, no distinction will be made in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: I can understand the Government not proceeding, in this legislation, to try to recover moneys that have been obtained by way of tax avoidance. It is certainly easier, in principle, to justify the attack on evasion. Certainly, it is necessary, I think, to recognise that the High Court of Australia, in its jurisdiction for a number of years, allowed various schemes as legal which were deplorable and quite contrary to the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been avoidance schemes.

—They were avoidance schemes because the High Court said they were legal. Everyone else would regard them as immoral and shocking, but they were allowed to exist so people proceeded with them. A number of those were later outlawed; they were illegal as from 1980. But I believe there is justification, therefore, in the Government restricting the legislation to evasions. There is some difference of view about this. The Australian Labor Party attitude to this Bill is considered in an interesting article by Terry McCrann in the Age of 3 November headed: 'Labor clarifies position on tax retrospectivity'. Senator Gareth Evans explained, in a general way and quite well, the Opposition's attitude towards this type of legislation. He started well, but when it came to saying how much further the Labor Party would have gone I think he immediately got into rather heavy water. The article stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he then proceeded to confuse the issue by saying that observers should not necessarily assume Labor would embark on a rash of retrospective legislation to recoup all the tax lost by all the artificial avoidance schemes. Yet Labor had not ruled out specific action against trust-stripping for one; each case would be considered on its 'merits'.
The writer then says:
Score one against Senator Evans. The electorate is entitled to a much clearer expression of just exactly how extensive Labor's retrospective action will be.

I will not go into the detailed argument in this but it does create a problem once one proceeds to on-their-merits arguments about which schemes will be attacked and which will not. Clearly in the case of evasion which the Government has chosen to legislate against there is a clear and good case. Blatant, contrived and artificial avoidance schemes have been put to rest for the future. But I believe that the Government should certainly try, to the greatest possible extent, to enforce legislation to collect moneys which can be recovered from people who were the beneficiaries of schemes in the past. The Government is in an unassailable position in this area. Even though there have been delays there will be no excuses for not collecting these taxes. Of course, if the Government did not proceed with that collection it would be subject to condemnation by the public which obviously appreciates the position very clearly.

I turn briefly to the amendments. This series of legislation has been considered in depth by the Government parties. I wish only that some other parts of the legislative program received the close investigation that has been given to this legislation; I would also like to see the same courtesy and attention given to people who have objections to legislation. Not always does that happen. I have studied the amendments as best I can. I am not, and never have been, any expert in tax avoidance, tax evasion or tax period in my 25 years as a lawyer. But the alterations appear to be minor. They have shown a state of care on the part of the Government in relation to people's rights and opportunities to protest to the courts. The legislation has been amended to include promoters. I think it is highly desirable that collections be made from them. Provision has been made for joint holders and people who may be jointly responsible for tax avoidance. I think that is eminently sensible. The important thing is that the Government has not conceded one inch anything to do with an 'innocence clause' because that would be a sell-out of this legislation. It would be better that no legislation came before us. How are we to stand by and prove what is in a crooked evader's mind? We will have to prove also what is in the mind of a person who gained benefit by tax evasion ten years ago. It would be the easiest thing in the world for a tax evader to say: 'I was advised by my lawyer that it was a good investment. I did not know that there was anything wrong. I am innocent'. He will then hope to escape.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which shower did they come down in?

—What shower did members of the Australian public come down in if they think that such an innocence clause would be of any value? I strongly urge those on this side of the chamber who speak of an innocence clause to realise that people cannot claim innocence because of a lack of knowledge. This innocence clause would completely downgrade the Bill. The Bill would lose all its credibility.
—What about minors?

—Parents put money into schemes and gain the benefit for children . It does not matter that they did or did not know. Somebody has to pay this tax . The person who ought to pay the tax clearly is the person who gained the benefit. Therefore, the question of innocence does not arise at all. I believe it is important to realise that these matters are within the peculiar knowledge of the people who gain. A lot of people, of course, did not bother to ask questions and were advised not to ask questions about the schemes which they entered into. I think it would be a waste of time for any government to move into the thicket of trying to disprove innocence. I find so very curious the remarks by the Law Council of Australia for which I generally have a fair amount of respect. I find its views on this legislation completely unconvincing. In an editorial in September the Law Council said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Law Council's position up to the present has been that the proposed retrospective measure is contrary to fundamental rights and freedoms.
I do not know what is meant by that. To my mind that is nonsense. The article continues:
It is wrong in principle and cannot be justified, particularly when the Federal Government has subsequently and successfully legislated to prevent this type of tax avoidance.

Of course it has so legislated but it must collect the money that has not already been paid. Nothing in its legislation had anything to do with that so that view is just a logical nonsense. The article continued:

The attitude of the Federal Government appears to be that the vendor shareholders must have known what was going on, and accordingly were parties to the fraud or at least knowing recipients of the proceeds from fraudulent conduct .

It does not follow from any of those things that they must have known. They knew that they were gaining a benefit. They knew that they were getting something worth much more than they were entitled to get. If they knew what they were doing in their businesses-the dictum of caveat emptor-they ought to have known about their dealings in the community. It is not a matter of their necessarily knowing of the fraud. The article continued:
Alternatively they say that the vendor shareholders are in just the same position as innocent purchasers of stolen property.
I think I agree with that generally. Those who innocently buy watches and so forth may find they have the same problem. The article further stated:
But the analogy is false: It has always been good law that such purchasers cannot obtain good title but never that vendor shareholders were liable for the company's tax.
That is just a little legal fiddle. The article continued:

It now seems inevitable that the legislation will be introduced. If this occurs then while the Law Council maintains its opposition to the legislation a minimum requirement must be to protect those persons who did not know that the taxation liability of the company would remain. There are many vendor shareholders who believed in one way or another that the entrepreneur would arrange for the liability to be expunged by lawful means.
Perhaps they did believe that. Perhaps they hoped that they would get away with it, but they will not get away with it because the taxpayers of Australia will not allow it. The article concluded:

There is every justification for providing that lack of knowledge in the taxpayer be a defence to the right to recover. This is not criminal legislation and there is no reason why the onus should not be cast upon the taxpayer to establish lack of knowledge. The Law Council will be doing everything in its power to bring this situation about.
I hope that it fails entirely in its aim. I think this is an example of where, unfortunately, the logic of the Law Council has entirely failed.

Opposition to the legislation has come from odd sources. It has come also from Western Australia. I read with pleasure the other day what my friend, the honourable and very honest Senator Andrew Thomas from Western Australia, had to say about the extent to which the opposition to this legislation, which has been promoted so much in that State, had permeated the Liberal Party. I notice that he withdrew the specific allegations and there is a somewhat garbled account as to when or where certain moneys were collected. Nonetheless, it is very clear that in Western Australia there has been much too much desire to improve the positions of and help the people who have made money quickly. It is time the Western Australian Liberals and other Liberals in this country who hold the same view got down to putting the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party back into the hands of the people who support the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer, the ordinary decent citizen of Australia. I believe this legislation is a great fight towards improving tax reform. There are a lot of other things to be done, but I commend the Government for the courage with which it has stood by its convictions in this area. I wish it every success with this legislation and with its vigorous enforcement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have listened to the debate I have come to the conclusion that virtually all that needs to be said has been said both in the Senate and in the other place. In fact, it made me think of the story that was told to me recently by somebody who has been here quite a long time. Shortly after being elected he made what he thought was a very good speech and puffed his chest out. One of the old timers pulled him aside and said: 'Young man, that was a very good speech. I made exactly the same points 15 years ago.' Although I am not making the same points 15 years after they were made previously, there are some I want to make very briefly with regard to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982 and the other Bills in the package. Their purpose is to enable the Government to collect tax which was not recoverable from companies because of certain manoeuvers and the disposal of the records of the companies- that is, they were dumped, as it were, at the bottom-of-the-harbour.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to make my position clear because I will support the second readings of these Bills but with very grave misgivings. We have all had a considerable amount of time to give this matter a lot of thought. We have heard from others of the length of time that these avoidance schemes have been going on and of the delays both within the Crown Solicitor's Office and also within the ranks of governments over the last few years. Senator Jessop yesterday, in what I think was a very thoughtful speech, detailed those delays very well. I refer interested people to his speech. In fact, I think it would be of advantage to many people to read the speeches made both here and in the other place because the debate has been thoughtful and many points of view have been put. I remind the Senate that in June 1978 I voted against the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill. It related to the Curran schemes and, I believe, the provisions were retrospective. Likewise, aspects of these Bills are retrospective. Certainly, the implications of being able to collect tax for the previous 10 years go along way. I operate a business and have done so for many years. I have kept my records for a long time. But those people who may have quite legitimately disposed of some of their records would have a lot of trouble in objecting to some of the assessments that might be handed out by the Australian Taxation Office. Certain persons did avoid payment of tax by using very artificial schemes. Out of fairness, in this case they should be made to repay those amounts.

Yesterday, Senator Grimes reminded the Senate that if a pensioner is overpaid for one reason or another, out of his very meagre income he has to repay that amount. The same principle in reverse should apply here. Justice and equity must apply equally to all taxpayers. In this case I take the broad view, that is, that justice to most taxpayers will be done by supporting this legislation. Justice to the average taxpayer will be better served by supporting this legislation with certain modifications. I believe that if such modifications can be made the legislation should be supported. One such modification is that we must ensure that those innocent of contriving benefits from these schemes will not be labelled. The fact that recoupment will be enforced only if the assessed amount exceeds $100 is not sufficient argument to my mind. I believe that the innocent must be protected. Senator Withers put it well in a letter to me recently in which he said:
We can't have decent, honest, respectable citizens being swept up and labelled with frauds, cheats, and intentional evaders by dragnet legislation.

That comment puts very well my reasons for feeling that the innocence provision should be included. We have heard how people can be innocent. Therefore, I will support the insertion of that clause. I still believe tax retrospectivity should be made illegal. Of course, that does not apply when somebody is given a benefit . If we seek to recoup that benefit, it does not matter how much later we get around to doing it, although it should be done quickly, of course. But when legislation imposes a penalty, retrospectivity is a very bad thing. The Constitution should be altered so that retrospectivity is made illegal as it is in the United States of America and France. I believe such a constitutional amendment would be understood by the people of Australia and would, I am sure, be passed.

Had the Government acted with sensible speed these Bills would not be necessary . The Government should realise that although I support these particular Bills I do so only after much anguish. For instance, if we establish a true precedent of retrospectivity we could open the door for retrospective income taxes and capital gains taxes. The Australian Labour Party has already said that these Bills do not go far enough. Earlier today Senator Withers said that we have made its bad policies respectable. He may not have used quite those words but that was certainly the import of what he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps not as fluently.

—I am not sure whether that is right. Thank you, but I think Senator Withers said: 'We have made their bad policies respectable'. I hope the people of Australia recognise that fact and realise that there is grave danger in electing a Labor Party to government ever again. I hope if cases such as ones that these Bills are meant to correct ever come to the notice of government or government departments, that we will not see the bureaucratic bungling that everybody knows has gone on. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) is responsible, if his Department does not act and does not inform him of what is going on. I hope in future the Government will act quickly and clearly. If it does not, I must say that it will not be able to count on my support for any retrospectivity. It is against the party platform and only in balance am I able to support these Bills. I do not believe anyone can feel safe if they are not able to plan their affairs in the certain knowledge that the rules of the game will not be altered retrospectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Senate is debating the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill 1982. The Opposition has moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of that Bill. First of all I wish to state quite plainly that as I understand it I am the last of the Mohicans-the last in a long line of speakers on this Bill. I hope that I can do justice to the debate. I will do so, if that is possible, within a period of five or 10 minutes. As Senator Townley said, the debate has ranged over almost all of the principles and issues that one could imagine when addressing one's mind to a subject of this character. I say at the outset that I regard the debate as being on a very high level. I congratulate those honourable senators who have put so much time into analysing this very important subject and into giving the Senate and, I believe, the public, the benefit of that reflection in such well chosen words in most cases. This Bill would not have been necessary had the Government taken action when it was so urged as far back as 1976 and 1977. From a reading of the documentation that has been tabled in the Senate thus far, it is clear, however, that one person at least comes out without egg on his face. That person is the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I say that reluctantly, but I have had a look at the documents. I must say publicly that the Prime Minister did urge the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to take urgent action about these schemes once the matter had been drawn to his attention. The Treasurer had the responsibility of taking action. There were significant delays in the Attorney-General's Department which are still as yet unexplained. The Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) condemns the abject failure of the Treasurer and the Government, knowing of the existence of straw company tax evasion schemes since at least 1978, to respond quickly and effectively to the massive tax evasion occurring through the use of such schemes.

Up to that point the amendment is unexceptionable. But paragraphs (b), (c) and ( d) of the amendment go well beyond the reasonable confines of the debate at this time. I would have thought that many honourable senators on the Government side who are opposing these Bills would support the first part of the Opposition's amendment; that is, paragraph (a). One of the arguments that has been advanced by Government speakers in opposing this Bill is that there is already in place legislation which should have been acted upon and pursued by the Government. As such, I believe that half a loaf is better than none. The Opposition may well consider, whilst I am concluding my remarks to the Senate on this matter, dropping paragraphs (b), (c) and (d) of its amendment and leaving paragraph (a) intact. That would, of course, challenge those who have spoken in similar terms to vote for that proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could do it yourself, couldn't you?

—Yes, I could amend it. I might try that, if that is an indication of the Opposition's view. The debate, as I see it thus far, has boiled down to two principles; that is, certainty before the law and fair shares . Those who advanced the principle of certainty before the law have suggested that an act which was legal some years ago should not now be clothed with illegality. Let us leave that aspect aside for one moment and address ourselves to the aspect of fair shares. I suggest that there is not one senator or, indeed , one member of parliament, and very few citizens of this country, who would defend the systematic bleeding of taxation revenue between 1972 and 1980 by the promoters of the schemes that have been described during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, we are all agreed on the principle of fair shares, but equally we have been confronted as a parliament and as a nation by the challenge of those promoters and those who have benefited from those schemes. The question is how to reverse that challenge and to ensure that the principle of fair shares is now accepted and implemented. How can we arrange things so that the ordinary pay-as- you-earn taxpayer does not have to continue to shoulder the burden of tax forgone by the existence of these artificial tax avoidance schemes? Herein lies a matter of real concern. The opponents of the legislation have stated clearly that the end does not justify the means. They have asserted that the Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill and its associated Bills are retrospective legislation and that at no stage should one clothe with illegality something that was previously legal. Let us analyse that for a moment. Can we elevate, if I may use that word, these schemes to that level? I believe we cannot. I suggest that one cannot say that those schemes were legal at the time. The best that one can say about them is that they may have had doubtful legality. The Brinsden opinion and other opinions testify to that fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't the Government try it in the court?

—Exactly; why did it not try them in the courts? That is what I am suggesting, Senator. That part of the Opposition's amendment is valid in that it describes the failure of the Government, knowing the existence of these straw company tax evasion schemes, to respond quickly and effectively to the massive tax evasion occurring through their use. I am in support of that part of its amendment. I am in opposition to the remainder of it.
—How do you feel about the principle of certainty?

—I thought I was attending to that at this time. What I am suggesting is that the principle of certainty before the law applies to those laws that are certain. If you ask any accountant or lawyer about taxation laws I guarantee that nine out of 10 will say that there is no certainty in taxation laws. It is perfectly clear that what the promoters of these schemes would have been told by their advisers is that it was a risk that they could take. It may be legal and it may not.
—Even if it was tested in the High Court?

—Yes, that is what I am saying. There is no certainty. One has to go right up to the High Court. There is a bunch of lawyers before that stage who have said that it is illegal and then it is tested in the High Court. I come back to the point of retrospectivity. I agree with the principle of certainty before the law and I am concerned with any suggestion that one should vote for retrospectivity where laws are certain. But what is retrospective about this legislation that is before us? The companies that are now at the bottom of the harbour were due to be assessed for company tax at $46 in every $100. That taxation was due to the Commonwealth Treasury at that time and is still due. So in that sense there is no retrospectivity in this legislation. It was an entitlement for the companies to pay that tax at that time. They still owe it; so there is no retrospectivity there. There is no suggestion that there is any attempt now to clothe the actions of the promoters, disastrous though their consequences for the internal revenue were, with criminal illegality, so there is no retrospectivity in that aspect. Where is the retrospectivity?
—In the Government's explanatory memorandum.
—The Government can say what it likes. I would suggest that what the Government says is that it is a new law.
—A new tax.

—It is a new tax, and the new tax is applied to whom? The new tax is applied to persons who are identified as having received a taxation benefit by virtue of their entry into an artificial scheme to avoid taxation. Under those circumstances, there is an argument that even that is not a retrospective tax. It is a new tax applied to persons who have derived a benefit . Those vendor-shareholders undeniably obtained a benefit by virtue of the fact that the companies in which they were shareholders were sold for a price which was unrealistically generous given the circumstances of the companies. It was unrealistically generous by reason of the fact that the company tax of $46 in every $100 of their profits was not paid to the Commissioner of Taxation and still is not paid. Those who have picked up the tab have been by and large the pay-as-you-earn taxpayers throughout the Commonwealth. The people who have derived the benefit, that is to say, the promoters and the vendor-shareholders, have, in some cases, had the money for perhaps eight years. It is not suggested in this legislation that they now pay the equivalent of that money to the Australian Taxation Office. This legislation, were it genuinely retrospective legislation, would say, 'That was the amount you owed. Multiply that by what inflation has run at and this is the amount that you pay now'. No, the legislation is not doing that. It is simply imposing a tax to the money value on persons identified by reason of their benefiting from those schemes. Unless I have used words tortuously, I have convinced-
—Hear, hear!

—I may not have convinced Senator Martyr, but I have convinced myself that this legislation does not clothe with illegality an act which was previously legal. Undoubtedly it imposes a tax on persons who previously would not have been eligible to pay it; so it is truly a new tax. I suggest that we come back to the question of fair shares. Having indicated that I agree with the principle of certainty before the law and that that principle is not in any way offended as I see it by this legislation, let us come to the question of fair shares. Should the ordinary taxpayer continue to pick up the tab, firstly, for those who have promoted the artificial tax avoidance schemes, and secondly, for those who have derived benefits therefrom? My suggestion is that they should not , and the principle of fair shares suggests that once those persons have been identified they should be asked now, by reason of this new tax, to pay at least some-not all of it but some-of their fair share in shouldering the burdens of this community.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that I would very strongly oppose retrospective legislation in this Parliament. I suggest that the high principles that have been advanced do not apply to the activities that have been engaged in by the promotors of the schemes and therefore I consider that in no way is this legislation offensive to the principles of certainty before the law and of fair shares. I support the legislation. As an amendment to the amendment moved by Senator Walsh, I move:
Leave out paragraphs (b), (c), and (d) of Senator Walsh's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second reading debate on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill and associated Bills has been extensive, in terms both of the time it has occupied and the matters that have been raised by honourable senators. It is interesting that the legislation has had support from members of the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Labor Party and from Senator Harradine. I thank all those honourable senators who have spoken for the spirit in which they have contributed to the debate. Perhaps because we have had so many speakers I should thank also those honourable senators who have not spoken. There are those like my colleague Senator Lewis, for instance, who would have spoken in support of the Bill. But the extensive list of Government speakers made Senator Lewis use his discretion not to speak on this occasion. I think as a result of what has been put by honourable senators we are better able to vote on this projected legislation tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: I could not hope, in this speech at the end of the second reading debate, to respond in detail to all the comments that have been made but I trust that the Senate will accept a response which picks up the main threads of what the various speakers have put, where they were making separate points. The very big issue of principle which has been aired is whether it is appropriate that we should now be legislating to cover events which occurred during a period now past, from 1972 to 1980. The Government remains of the view that the legislation is an appropriate response to the situation and is not subject to valid objection on the score of retrospectivity. A great deal has been said about that by a number of speakers. The legislation addresses circumstances in which companies have been so stripped of funds that they are unable to pay very large amounts of tax which were and still are legally payable. An element of illegality was, on the part of at least some of those involved in the overall arrangements, present in each one of these cases. Companies were denuded of funds in a way that quite disregarded the claims of the revenue, and beyond it the general public, to the income tax which the companies had come under an obligation to pay. But in saying that I want to nail another notion that I have heard expressed, that is that the legislation somehow makes illegal what was legal at the time. It does nothing of the sort. Having given those directly concerned the opportunity to contest the claim by the Commissioner of Taxation, what the legislation does is to say that the amount of company tax that remains unpaid is to be recouped from those groups, vendors and promoters who benefited from its non-payment.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was speaking on the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill. I was responding to some of the claims that were made during the second reading debate on the Bill. I continue by saying that the call for recoupment puts no additional taint or brand on those concerned. When that is recognised-as I hope it will be-it becomes clearer that the legislation is a justifiable exercise of the power that the Parliament unquestionably enjoys. In exercising our responsibility to legislate for a fair and equitable tax system we must, in the view of the Government, on this occasion act in a way that is formally retrospective but in a way that simply recoups benefits flowing from the evasion of legally payable tax.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of innocence of vendor- shareholders will come up again during the Committee stage of the Bill. Let me say at this point that when the legislation is not making illegal anything that was legal but is just affecting recoupment of unpaid tax any state of innocence on the part of vendors is not to the point. I say that with all due respect to those of my colleagues who think otherwise. Let me add that, while I differ from them on this matter, I do acknowledge that they conscientiously hold a different view and it is quite wrong for them to be classed, as some have done, as friends of the vendors and evaders of tax. I also suggest that it is not helpful to the resolution of the question that is now before us to seek, as some honourable senators have, to make points about prosecutions not having been launched in the past against those who were active in the promotion of pre-tax profit stripping schemes. That has already been the subject of extensive debate in the Parliament. It is just a matter of repetition to go over that ground again. What is important is the action that is being taken at present.

As a government we have acted to establish in office a special prosecutor to pursue matters under the criminal law. The work of the Special Prosecutor is well under way. The question of criminal actions is one for the Special Prosecutor. It was legislation of this Government, introduced in 1980-the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act-that dealt a mortal blow to pre-tax profit stripping schemes. I have heard it said again in this debate that that legislation was too long in coming. Those who say that, however, fail to take into account the necessity there was of ensuring that attainment of a desirable objective was affected with fairness to those who might have been caught up in it. In the present situation the Government is attacked by Opposition senators for having, in the course of producing legislation that meets reasonable points of criticism and attains proper standards of fairness, varied the legislation in one way or another. Sub-clause (12) of clause 3 is a particular example of that. The sub- clause does not represent the significant loophole in the legislation that those honourable senators have made it out to be. Again, I will expand on that at the Committee stage.

I use this opportunity to say something about the revenue estimates. The Australian Taxation Office has now identified some 4,900 companies that were, in the period concerned, stripped of pre-tax profits. The primary tax evaded in these cases totalled some $500m. The undistributed profits tax amounted to some $120m. The Commissioner of Taxation has estimated that about 10 per cent, or $ 60m, of this will be uncollectable. On top of that the Commissioner estimates that about $40m will be excluded from recoupment by sub-clause (12) of clause 3, so that total recovery under the legislation is now put at a figure of about $ 520m. It is also estimated that $100m of this amount will be collected in 1982- 83. Changes in the original proposal, such as the decision to give vendors a chance to contest the basic assessment of company tax, have contributed to the fall-off in current year collections. Some people see the granting to vendors of this facility of payment by instalments as another element of delay. In some situations that would be true, but in others again the facility is expected to advance the recovery process.

I come now to further aspects of the Opposition's proposed amendment to the second reading of the Bill, which I trust the Senate will reject. No one who has followed this matter with any care could support the notion that the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) and the Government have, as suggested, failed to respond quickly and effectively. It is all very well to suggest otherwise with the benefit of today' s knowledge and insights but the information then available, even in 1980, presented nothing like the picture available today. As has been said before, the Government has acted with resolution consistent with the need to exercise care in framing legislation such as that of 1980, which I remind the Senate was described by the Opposition as being of an unprecedented nature.

The Opposition amendment suggests that the Bill is inadequate on two counts- that it does not recoup personal income tax lost in the course of pre-tax profit strips and that it does not extend to sales tax. I suggest that the sales tax point can be dealt with quite shortly. Fundamentally, there is not, as in the case of income tax, the same clear loss of revenue. Rather, the Commissioner of Taxation believes that he has substantial prospects of upholding sales tax assessments against companies that are in a position to pay the tax. The Opposition contention about the recovery of personal income tax is useful for the gap that it exposes between the thinking of the Opposition and the Government. We say that the proper scope of legislation such as this is the recoupment of tax that has always been legally payable. The Opposition puts, but the Government does not accept, that the tax that has simply been avoided should be the subject of these retrospective tax measures. It is no indication of lack of concern to observe that this category of avoidance is no worse than others in respect of which legislation has been made purely prospective in application. I remind the Senate that it was this Government that, through new Part IVA, legislated to stop tax avoidance through dividend stripping and similar schemes. That legislation has operated since 27 May 1981.

This brief summary concludes my remarks at this stage. I urge the Senate to reject the Opposition's amendment to the motion for the second reading and to pass the Bill as it stands. I make similar comments in regard to Senator Harradine's amendment to the Opposition's amendment.
Amendment (Senator Harradine's) to the amendment (Senator Walsh's) negatived.

That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walsh's amendment) be added.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

—I do not want to have any debate on this matter, otherwise senators will have to seek leave from the chamber. —by leave-Mr President, as Senator Withers has taken this opportunity to make clear how Senator Martin and Senator Bonner would vote, I point out that also paired are Senator Mulvihill, Senator Georges, Senator Button and Senator Tate.
