Clause 3 (Interpretation).

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not move yet the amendment to sub-clause (12) which has already been circulated. The first question I want to ask relates to sub-clause (2) of clause 3 which incidentally was not in the original legislation introduced into the House of Representatives on 23 September. I understand that the effect of that clause is to exclude from liability persons who were acting as directors in a capacity incidental to their professional capacity, presumably as accountants or lawyers. My question is, firstly, whether that is broadly correct and, secondly, I seek the Government's reason for the addition of that sub-clause to the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill as it was originally presented on 23 September.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sub- clause (2) makes it clear that a person will not be taken to be a director of a company merely because the directors act on advice given by that person in a professional or business capacity. I would have thought that that was quite self -explanatory. It is clear that the sub-clause and its insertion is for that purpose.

—I am sorry, I did not clearly hear the first dozen or so words of the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle). It is not perfectly clear to me. Only a few days ago a Queen's Counsel of my acquaintance described certain clauses of this Bill as being written in a mixture of Swahili and Afghan as if the intention were to prevent people from understanding it. I will confess that I often have difficulty understanding legislation but in this case even professionals have difficulty. It is still not clear to me. I thought my question was simple enough. Does this sub-clause exclude from liability people who exercise the powers of directors but in a capacity which is incidental-when they are acting as directors-to their professional advice or service such as an accountant or lawyer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said , clause 12 (2) of the Bill will make it clear that a person will not be taken to be a director merely because directors act on advice given by that person in a professional business capacity. —Can the Minister explain how somebody who is a professional adviser to a director, and nothing else, could ever have been affected by this legislation? It does not impose any criminal penalties but seeks to make people responsible for paying tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a clarifying clause because the definition of 'director' in relation to a company includes any person, 'in accordance with whose directions or instructions the directors of a company are accustomed to act'. It is there for that purpose.

—I am not satisfied with that answer but it is pretty clear there is no point in pursuing it. Sub-clause (6) of clause 3 was not in the original legislation, nor was sub-clause (8) of clause 3 in the original legislation. I seek from the Minister the Government's reasons for the inclusion of those sub-clauses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sub- clauses referred to are inserted in the Bill for the reasons defined in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. If Senator Walsh looks at the memorandum he will see the definitions of the clauses that seem to worry him. Sub-clause (6) applies in relation to a purchase of shares and mirrors the application of the sub-clause in relation to a sale of shares. That is the reason it is included in the Bill. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Pages 6 and 7, clause 3, sub-clause (12), leave out the sub-clause.

Sub-clause (12) was not contained in the legislation when it was introduced on 23 September-the first version of the Bill. As I stated last week, this is the Horgan amendment. I will leave aside the question of what it is designed to do. Its effect will be to allow Denis Horgan-the former finance committee vice- chairman of the Western Australian Liberal Party-to keep the several million dollars of tax which was not paid by companies of which he was a major shareholder. The effect will be to allow that powerful, influential Liberal to keep several million dollars which were designated by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) a couple of months ago as having been stolen. If this sub-clause remains in the Bill the situation is that if a person has a company and puts it into a tax avoidance scheme, which subsequently fails, and that person retains the company after the scheme fails that person will have to pay the tax. If he owns a company with current year profits, puts it into a tax avoidance scheme, sells it to a promoter such as Brian Maher, who then sells the company to a painter or docker or some other sham director and the scheme then fails, nobody pays the tax. If a person with a company with current year profits sells it to a dealer like Brian Maher, who then puts it through a tax avoidance scheme, sells it to a painter or docker or some sham director and the tax avoidance scheme then fails, nobody pays. That is the effect of this clause. If I heard the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) correctly when she was replying to the second reading debate, the current estimate of the cost to revenue of the insertion of this clause is $100m.

I say this is the Horgan amendment because the principal Horgan company, Treamog Ltd, which was covered to some extent in the McCabe-Lafranchi report, was put into such a tax avoidance scheme. The transcript of evidence given to the McCabe-Lafranchi inquiry by Lee Hurley, an associate of Maher's, on page 6949 shows quite clearly that Treamog was put into a tax avoidance scheme after it was acquired by Maher. I interpolate there that the tax problems referred to were a current year profit of something over $3.7m. That somehow or other had to be eliminated before the balance date of 31 December. Hurley replied:

I do not know, and the secrecy provisions of the Taxation Act probably preclude me from finding out or the Senate being told, whether that specific share trading avoidance arrangement was disallowed by the Commissioner of Taxation. Whether it has been disallowed at this stage or not, we do know that a number of schemes which had previously been successful, which might be loosely described as Curran-type schemes, are being contested in the courts by the Commissioner, and with some success. So whether that particular scheme has failed or not, there is a very real possibility it will fail at some time in the future.

If clause 3 (12) had not been inserted in this Bill the current year tax liability of about $1.7m, from a current year profit, according to the figures disclosed in the McCabe-Lafranchi report, of $3.7m, would have had to be paid by the shareholders. Directly and indirectly Denis Horgan owned about 60 per cent of the shares in that company and therefore he personally will, because of the insertion of this clause, be allowed to retain in round figures one million stolen dollars, as the Prime Minister called them. There is no clearer evidence of the corruptibility of this Government than the fact that this clause has been inserted. All the strong rhetoric about cracking down on tax evaders, of making these people who have stolen money pay it back, falls to the ground because this clause has been inserted. The entire rationale for the existence of this legislation disappears because of the insertion of this and two or three other clauses. From the outset the Government has asserted that because this legislation deals only with acts which were illegal and fraudulent at the time they were committed, therefore all the transactions were void.

The rationale for the introduction of this legislation is that it will simplify and speed up the collection of tax which could have been collected under the old laws because the actions were fraudulent and illegal. Because of the insertion of this clause it is virtually guaranteed that most, if not all, of the companies affected by the legislation, if there is a substantial tax liability, will litigate their liability. The insertion of this clause has guaranteed that there will be very considerable litigation before the money can be recovered. The insertion of a couple of other clauses to which we will come later, such as those relating to the time within which payment is required and the reduction in the penalty for late payment, will obviously delay the collection of whatever timely amount of money is left, but this clause more than anything else undermines the Government's own rationale for the Bill because it will take most of the substantial cases into the courts. The avoidance of such litigation was said by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his statement of 25 July to be the major reason for the introduction of this legislation. Above all, the insertion of this clause shows the corruptibility of this Government. If one is a powerful figure in the Liberal Party and is a heavy enough contributor to its funds one can have clauses written into government legislation to exclude one from liability to repay what the Prime Minister said was stolen money.

With something less than admiration I noted his subsequent retraction when people in the Liberal Party in Perth stood over him. I noted with some amusement the denial of Mr W. W. Mr Mitchell is quoted directly as follows:

I would have thought that that was confirmation of Senator Thomas's original charge rather than a denial of it. It is further acknowledged by the Government that that will occur in the context of a chain of transactions in which the company in question is ultimately stripped and dumped in the sense of being put in the bottom of the harbour or in some other way reduced to a shadow of its former self and unable to be proceeded against in practical ways by the Commissioner.

An extraordinary assertion is being made, and is made no less extraordinary when one considers the way in which, up until just a few weeks ago, the Government was resolutely refusing to acknowledge a relevant distinction morally between tax avoidance on the one hand and tax evasion on the other. That is a relevant distinction when we are talking, for example, about the application of criminal penalties to tax cheating operations. It is appropriate that criminial penalties be applied in the case of tax evasion . It is not appropriate, in my view, that criminal penalties ever be applied, retrospectively or otherwise, in the context of tax avoidance, but that is not an appropriate distinction when avoidance and evasion are bound up in the very same series of transactions and that is exactly what is involved in these cases.

This legislation only begins to bite when the company in question is ultimately stripped of its assets in such a way as to become unable to meet the tax liability falling due as assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation. This legislation is only applicable, in other words, when there has, at the end of the chain of transactions, been some fraudulent stripping arrangement. This is the pay-off to the Horgans. This is the pay-off to hundreds of other supporters of this particular Government who have been pressing the Government for action to protect them which would have embarrassed the Government to do more overtly than it has in this particular clause. Clause 3 (12) is a retreat of a very expensive kind so far as the Government is concerned, expensive in terms of revenue and expensive in terms of the principles which the Government has sacrificed in the process.

—I am not sensitive about it. Delicacy is not involved. I ask Senator Walsh, through you, Mr Chairman, to withdraw the imputation against me.

—The Chair has not seen it as an imputation against the honourable senator. The honourable senator is entitled to make a speech after Senator Walsh has resumed his seat. At this stage there is no point of order.

—Particularly as Senator Chipp expressed a desire to listen to further debate on this amendment I would like, as simply as I possibly can, to go through the effect that it would have. If sombody who owns a company with current year profits puts those profits into a tax avoidance scheme which the Commissioner of Taxation ultimately disallows that person will have to pay the tax; that is, of course, independent of clause 3 (12). But clause 3 (12) would ensure-the Minister appeared to deny this but it is in her second reading speech which she made a couple of weeks ago-that it also affected pre-sale tax avoidance schemes. If a person with a company with a current year profits puts those profits into a tax avoidance scheme and then sells the company to a tax promoter who, before the scheme was disallowed, was lucky enough to have passed the company on to a sham director and stripped all the money from the company, nobody pays the tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at those two instances. Surely any reasonable person would conclude that the company owner who tried the tax avoidance scheme which failed is less culpable than the company owner who tried the tax avoidance scheme and than sold it to a promoter, especially if the process of sale to the promoter required that all the assets of the company be turned into cash. That was the basis on which, if not all almost all, these schemes operated. A company which was actually producing something, carrying on some legitimate business, would sell off all its assets to another company still under the control of the same people , which company than carried on the business. But everything that the target company, the original company, owned was turned into cash.

In the case of Treamog Ltd-according to the McCabe-Lafranchi report-total funds of $6.536m were involved. All the company had was money, it was not producing anything. It was not conducting any business. The business which it had once conducted had been sold off. In many cases the business was then still conducted by the same people using all the same physical assets but operating under a different name. So the company had nothing but money to sell. The vendor shareholders than sold all the money for 95 cents in the dollar, as they did in the case of Treamog, even though as in the specific case of Treamog again-the annual report of the company, which was drawn up just a month before it was sold , showed provision for taxation of $2.168m. In that case a promoter paid 95 cents for every dollar of cash that the company had even though there was a known tax liability of 33 cents in every dollar that the company had. We are asked to believe-certainly by 10 Government senators but I think the Government as a whole-that that person should be regarded as innocent. He sold nothing but money, sold every dollar for 95c but with a tax liability at that time of 33c. That is exactly what happened in the Treamog case.

Because of the insertion of this clause the vendor-shareholders of Treamog and some hundreds of other companies-nobody can really know at this stage how many hundred that will be-who essentially went through all of those steps, turned everything that the companies owned into cash and then sold the cash for 95 per cent of its face value with a tax liability of 33c, are to be excluded from paying any of the tax providing either they, or the promoter, went through the process of a tax avoidance scheme which they have to demonstrate objectively could have been expected to succeed. I suggest that all they will have to do to demonstrate that it could have been expected to succeed is to produce half a dozen accountants, lawyers, staff of promoters and agents who will stand up in court and swear that they expected it to succeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying they would perjure themselves?
—No, they might have quite genuinely expected it to succeed. At the time when Barwick was on the bench one could have expected, I think quite reasonably, almost anything to succeed.
—He had only one vote.
—Yes. He had a lot of influence though because there have been a few different decisions since.
—Are you reflecting on the other members?
—Reflecting on the other members? I will be quite happy to have a debate about Barwick's record in the High Court some other time. I do not intend to do that tonight.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator stick to the clause.
—You can reflect on most of them; they are dead.

—Not quickly enough. If somebody arranged his own tax avoidance scheme and kept the company he would have to pay the tax. If a promoter arranged a tax avoidance scheme and was involved in a transaction so transparently non- commercial that he was selling nothing but money for less than its face value but with a substantial tax liability accompanying it he is to be let off as long as somebody put it through the process of a tax avoidance scheme. Essentially, that is what this clause does. I cannot believe that this Government would destroy the logic of its own taxation policy, wipe out all its credibility, or any shred of credibility it may have left on the question of clamping down on tax avoidance and evasion, and indeed destroy the basic rationale for the Bill itself, that rationale being that this legislation is necessary to keep all these matters out of court and to speed up collection, by then subsequently inserting a clause which guarantees that a substantial number of them at least will be litigated in court. I do not believe that even this Government, as crazy as its economic policies may have been from time to time, and still are, would have inserted a clause like that unless there was a very good reason for it. I suggest that, among other things, one reason-unless there were very good reasons for it-is that this company, Treamog Ltd, clearly comes within the scope of that sub-clause. I do not think we will get any support from the Government side on this because the people on the Government side seem to think that the Bill is too tough even though it has been watered down.
—We don't all think it is too tough.

—I appeal to Senator Missen then to really think about what this clause means. I appeal to the Australian Democrats and to Senator Harradine to really think about what it means and to at least toughen up the legislation to the extent that that massive loophole is removed from the Bill before it passes through the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having heard the latter-day Mellors give vent to his rage about the High Court of Australia, I thought I should say something about it. It is remarkable that the High Court is coming in for a large amount of abuse from all sorts of people in all sorts of sectors of society as though it were the maker of tax avoidance or evasion. I have been a member of this place for a reasonable time. From memory, Sir Garfield Barwick became Chief Justice of the High Court in about 1964. One thing about High Court judgments, of course, is that they are all public-they are published. Since I came to this place in 1966, how many petitions have been presented each day by the Australian Labor Party about the wicked judgments of the High Court and how this terrible man Barwick was allowing the tax system to be ripped off? How many notices of motion have been given? How many questions have been asked? How many matters of public importance have there been? How many urgency motions have there been? How many adjournment speeches have there been? The reaction of the Opposition during the period when Sir Garfield Barwick was allegedly allowing the tax avoiders and evaders to rip off the community was total silence.
—A cheap debating point.

—No. There was silence until recently when it became fashionable for everybody to do it. One virtually never heard Sir Garfield Barwick's name mentioned in this place until after the events of 1975. Ever since then members of the Opposition have been venting their spleen on this great and sound lawyer, perhaps one of the great advocates of the century. It is a pity that this sort of vendetta should be maintained against Sir Garfield Barwick. It is all very easy to have scapegoats. All politicans on both sides have their favourite scapegoats, be they multinational, militant trade unions or constitutions. Everybody has to have a scapegoat. Maybe my scapegoat is the two Mellors sitting in the front row of the Opposition benches. Why keep making Sir Garfield Barwick the scapegoat for the tax avoidance and evasion industry of Australia? I have no doubt at all that during the period these judgments were coming down from the High Court the Commissioner of Taxation was urging a series of Treasurers-who had more Treasurers than Whitlam, I cannot imagine-to amend the legislation because of the loopholes which the High Court was finding in the existing Acts. I think it is high time more people on my side of politics defended the High Court. If tax avoidance and evasion got away in this country-
—Are you booking a seat?

—Why not? It is high time the real blame for the growth of tax avoidance and evasion in this country was put where it should be put; that is, in the Parliament. Not one High Court decision could not have been corrected by legislation the next day. The Parliament was almost as lethargic and negligent in dealing with the decisions of the High Court as were some people dealing with prosecutions in the Attorney-General's Department. I fail to see why the High Court should be the scapegoat. I repeat: It is high time the Parliament accepted the blame for the tax avoidance and evasion industry getting out of hand. I am sick and tired of the High Court being the whipping boy for our own mistakes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I should make a short comment on some of the things said since I outlined the tests that have to be applied before this section may apply. I want to respond to what Senator Walsh said when he sought to draw a distinction between the case of a post-sale attempted avoidance scheme and one in which there was an attempted avoidance scheme before the vendors sold their shares. Clause 3 sub- clause (12) does not apply in the latter case. However because of sub-paragraph (c) (ii) of clause 5 sub-clause (7) that latter case will be outside the legislation if, at the time of sale, there was on an objective view a reasonable expectation that the scheme would succeed and the company had not then been assessed by the Commissioner of Taxation. The objective test is one to be determined in the first instance by the Commissioner of Taxation applying the test of reasonable means. If and when it gets to a court the promoter may put forward what his expectation was but that does not give the answer. The court must resolve the matter not on what the promoter thought but on the basis of a reasonable man's view of the scheme's likely success. I think Senator Walsh has been talking about the insertion of the clause guaranteeing that there would be a lot of litigation. I think that we ought to remind the Senate that in most cases there was no attempt at all to add a post-sale avoidance scheme. In those cases there would be nothing to litigate in reliance on this sub-clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chipp has referred to the likely difficulties of administration. I do not think that anyone would suggest that there are not difficulties in the whole of the administration, particularly of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I think that whatever difficulties there might be in the administration of a complex Act they should not be a reason for deleting a provision that otherwise would be justified. We believe that this sub-clause is justified. I reiterate that the Government rejects the Opposition's amendment which suggests that the sub-clause be deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

If I heard the Minister for Finance ( Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) correctly about 20 minutes ago she said that clause 3 sub-clause (12) was only applicable where a post-sale tax avoidance scheme was attempted. In his second reading speech Senator Sir John Carrick said that it applies to a post-sale scheme. He said:

In the next paragraph it is stated:
In line with that, the recoupment legislation will also not apply where there was a pre-sale avoidance scheme which, though ultimately shown to be unsuccessful--

And so on through to the reference to the objective test. What is the position? Will clause 3 sub-clause (12) apply to cases where there was an attempt at an avoidance scheme both before and after sale as the second reading speech states or only after sale as I understood the Minister to say about 20 minutes ago?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me clarify the situation. The subsequent paragraph read by Senator Walsh does not refer to clause 3 sub-clause (12); it is a separate provision altogether.
—What does it refer to?
— It refers to clause 5, sub-clause (7) (c) (ii) .

—I will be very brief. I want to say how much I appreciate the lucid explanations given by Senators Walsh and Evans when explaining the Australian Labor Party's amendment. I congratulate both of them on their speeches. I am persuaded by them that if I voted for the thrust of this legislation I would have to support the Labor Party amendment. I know honourable senators such as Senator Missen hold very strong views on this. However, I am disappointed that Senator Missen has remained silent because I respect his views on this subject. I would have thought that if honourable senators support the retrospectivity of this legislation, as Senator Missen has done in this case, the arguments of Senator Walsh and Senator Evans are unanswerable. Because I quite clearly rejected the concept of retrospectivity in this legislation I cannot support this amendment. I am not trying to score any point off Senator Missen. I suppose I am acknowledging the force of logic of the speeches of the two Opposition speakers. However, I cannot accept or support the amendment for the reasons I have given.

—I will speak very briefly on this matter. I have listened to the debate carefully. I certainly have been concerned with this clause for some time. I know it is one to which an amendment has been moved. I hope the Government has not gone too far in making these provisions. I can see very little merit in the concession given to people in this regard. The Government makes a big thing of the difference between tax avoidance and evasion . It is a distinction which I do not personally make but, of course, there is a distinction between the two terms throughout the whole of this legislation. I remain unconvinced by the answers given by the Government on this clause concerning extensive amounts of money which will not be recovered. But I am not an expert in any way on this subject. I hope the Government is right. I am prepared to go with its judgment on this matter. I am not sufficiently convinced , certainly by the explanations that have been given.

—The Australian Labor Party is indebted to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for explaining what until now I had thought was simply a misprint in her second reading speech. She told us that the reference to the recoupment legislation not applying where there was a pre-sale avoidance scheme which might reasonably have been expected to become successful was indeed exactly what she meant. She justified that by reference to the language of clause 5 (7) (c) (ii). Indeed, when one reads clause 5 (7) (c) (ii) it does become quite clear that what is being said there is that for the purposes of calculating the amount of the company tax liability of a company one should take into account not just the liability which is in fact owing in respect of company tax for such a company but the amount of company tax that might reasonably be expected to be owing had an avoidance scheme that was set in train but which proved unsuccessful, in fact been successful. We were told earlier that the loss to revenue by virtue of the operation of clause 3 (12) would be $40m. I ask Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle whether she will now tell us precisely the amount of revenue loss that this bit of deft legislative redefinition in fact involves and whether it is not very much more substantial than $40m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —That figure was based on the original Bill. As I am advised, we cannot place any figure on it at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -I thank Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle for clarifying this matter. It was apparently my misunderstanding. Probably we will investigate the matter that Senator Evans raised in more detail tomorrow.
—That sounds ominous.

—I think a lot of honourable senators on the other side will want to say a lot about some of their amendments. Although Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has clarified the situation this makes little difference to the essential point about the effect of clause 3 (12). I take Senator Chipp's point. I agreed with him entirely when he said that anyone who supported the basic thrust of this Bill, so far as it goes, logically should support the amendment. He then said that he does not support the basic thrust of the Bill because he believes the whole Bill is unjust. But I put it to him that even for somebody who holds that view, surely it is more unjust with this clause in than it would be with this clause out, for this reason: If one tries a tax avoidance scheme to wipe out a current year profit and it fails, one has to pay the tax. Now we have the clarification. If the company is sold to someone like Brian Maher, but before selling all its assets are turned into money and then the money is sold for 95 cents in the dollar, knowing that being sold with it is a contingent tax liability of 33 cents in the dollar, and then after the event of the sale, because of sheer good luck, the dealer attempts a tax avoidance scheme, no tax has to be paid. Nobody has to pay any tax under those circumstances provided the dealer takes the extra precaution of flogging off the bankrupt company to a painter or docker or some other sham director. Surely it is even more unjust to allow people who behaved in the way that the vendor-shareholders of Treamog Ltd did, and however many thousand other companies there were in exactly the same category, to escape from tax liabilities, when somebody who in a more or less honest way attempted a tax avoidance scheme of his own-insofar as there is any honesty in this whole area-has to pay. Even for those who think the Bill as a whole is unjust, I put it to them that it is even more unjust with this clause than it would be without it.

That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Walsh's amendment) be left out.

Clause 4 (Application of Assessment Act).

TALK.START.PARA: —Sub-clause 8 of clause 4 is another sub -clause that was not in the original Bill presented to the House of Representatives on 23 September. Section 209 of the Income Tax Assessment Act broadly sets in train legal action for recovery of tax liabilities. Proceedings under that clause will not be taken unless notice of assessment has been served on the person and the Commissioner of Taxation has served notice in writing that proceedings will be taken within 30 days unless the tax is paid. Suppose somebody who knew he had a significant liability under this Bill skipped the country before an assessment could be served on him and he decided that he would stay outside the country. Does this mean that no action could be taken against him unless he subsequently returned to Australia and put himself in the position where the assessment could be served on him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 8, clause 4, after sub-clause (3), insert the following new sub-clause :
''(3A) A report of the Commissioner under section 14 of the Assessment Act may-
(a) draw attention to the failure of a person to pay recoupment tax or late payment tax due and payable by the person; and
(b) disclose the identity of the person.''.

This amendment relates to the subsequent publication in the annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation of the names of vendor-shareholders affected by this legislation. Neither the original clause-that is, original to the Government's Bill-nor the one that is in the Bill that is before us now, as I read it, makes it mandatory for the Commissioner to name vendor-shareholders affected by the legislation. But the provision in the Bill as it is before the Committee makes it much less likely that the vendor-shareholders would be named in the Taxation Commissioner's annual report. The original 23 September provision, which we are attempting to reinsert, states that a report of the Commissioner under section 14 of the Income Tax Assessment Act may draw attention to the failure of a person to pay recoupment tax or late payment tax due and payable by the person and disclose the identity of that person. That was what the Government originally had in the Bill and subsequently decided to replace with what is in the Bill before us. I will not read it out; it is rather lengthy. The effect is to make it much less likely that such persons will be named in the Commissioner' s report.

I thought that the arguments put up by Government members in the House of Representatives for resisting this amendment when we moved it there were particularly spurious, remembering that the people concerned have been proclaimed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), amongst others, to be thieves and criminals, people who were involved in fraudulent, illegal activity. By definition, according to the Government, the people who would be likely to have their names published are those who are guilty of fraudulent and illegal activities, with the possible exception, of course, of the odd vendor- shareholder who actually did not know what was going on. However, they would be a very small minority. It seems to me that, again, the reason that the Government changed its mind and its original Bill is its anxiety to protect from exposure people who have influence, particularly in the Liberal Party.

The only penalty that could be imposed on the great majority of people who would be affected by this clause is the penalty of exposure, nothing else. I do not believe that the Government has put up any valid reasons for changing its original intention. I think that there is at least as good a reason for naming in the report of the Commissioner of Taxation not only people who, in the great majority of cases, are engaged in what Mr Fraser says is fraudulent and illegal activity but also people who have not paid up when called upon to do so as there is for naming other tax avoiders and evaders. They have been named probably ever since the Income Tax Assessment Act has been in existence. I hope that the Senate will accept our amendment which, like the previous amendment, I stress, only seeks to restore provisions in the Government's Bill which were in the Bill which the Government itself introduced into the House of Representatives six or eight weeks ago.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh again makes the assertion that the deletion of a clause which was in the original Taxation ( Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill has been done for the benefit of the Liberal Party of Australia. I find that absolutely remarkable in terms of its logic but not in the least remarkable in terms of its coming from Senator Walsh. To me, this amendment epitomises all the distasteful elements of the public debate which has been carried on by the Australian Labor Party in the public arena seeking in an artificial way to promote rage, indignation and intemperate comments to the point where there is no distinction between innocence and guilt, avoidance and evasion.
—The Prime Minister wasn't distinguishing between them either until John Reid got caught.

—I do not ever pretend to be visited by the accidental mistakes made by any member of the Government or the Opposition. One assumes that the object of the clause proposed by Senator Walsh is to ensure the public vilification of presumably in many cases innocent people, to ensure judgment of people by the public in many cases, to put on trial publicly those people who may in a dispute ultimately be found to be thoroughly innocent and thoroughly justified in their objection to an assessment that is applied to them by the Commissioner of Taxation. It is intended, in my view, to humiliate the respectable people in the community who are simply seeking to contest an assessment which is put before them. Of course, it represents a complete change of the provisions of section 14, I think it is, of the Income Tax Assessment Act , which presently provides that those listed in the annual report primarily are those who breach the Act or are subject to evasion. Implicit in that, in many respects, is the question of guilt. It has been argued long and hard in this debate that the legislation is not about innocence or guilt. But if this amendment does not seek, more than anything else, to imply guilt to individuals, I do not know what does. It removes the original intention, wording and thrust of the provision to the point where it is now being abused and prostituted to the stage of attaching additional names for one of two purposes-to intimidate people into paying taxes which they may well be challenging themselves or to hold them up to vilification and to public ridicule. Taxation is a complex matter and invariably if people see names in the Commissioner's annual report they will judge those named guilty. It is perhaps a sad indictment upon our community but that is the situation at the present time.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect that one of the great casualties of this debate on this issue is the standing of this Parliament which hitherto has been held to be somewhat fragile. Individual members over recent months have sought by their own prejudices, hates , obsessions and distortions of truth to reduce the standing of this Parliament. I think by this clause we are seeking to reduce the standing of the community as well as our own. The fact that we have used parliamentary privilege and we are now seeking to use an insidious system to vilify these people further does not, I believe, reflect well upon this Parliament. I suspect that many people are going to be damaged and destroyed by attacks upon them by individuals in this Parliament under the cloak of parliamentary privilege. I do not think we ought to add to the indiscriminate, imprecise, irresponsible and concocted attacks by the political parties who are putting forward this amendment. For my part, I think it is intended simply to intimidate people and to try to make presumably innocent people guilty in the eyes of the public. If that is its intention, I cannot be a party to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This sub- clause was in fact included in the original Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill. It would specifically entitle the Commissioner of Taxation to name in his annual report a person who fails to pay recoupment tax payable by that person. The Government reviewed the provision and concluded that it was an extension of the Commissioner's reporting function. The Government decided that it ought not to be adopted in connection with this recoupment tax legislation.
—Why?

—The reason was that simple failure to pay ought not to lead to persons being named publicly because there are possibilities of injustice in adopting such a course. Perhaps I ought to say that the general reporting responsibility of the Commissioner is to name people who have committed breaches or evasions of the tax law. A simple failure to pay has not been regarded as a breach or evasion warranting the formal naming of a person by the Commissioner. For that reason it was decided that we would not insert a provision that extended the Commissioner's reporting function in that way.

—Could I add one more observation, just to get this in clear perspective? As I understand the house rules at the present time they are that one is not named unless the penalty is in excess of $1,500 or it is an amount of 25 per cent or more of the evaded tax. To that extent, there is already a qualification as to people mentioned in the annual report. This amendment does not even include that house rule qualfication .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently Senator Crichton-Browne is unable to understand why anyone might be led to suspect that changes could be made to the Government's Bill to benefit monetarily and otherwise prominent members of the Liberal Party of Australia. I find that really quite astounding, coming from a Western Australian member of the Liberal Party, as at least five members of the finance committee of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal Party have been identified in documentary evidence-records of the Corporate Affairs Office-which shows that they have sold companies to the Maher organisation. The last time I had a list there were only 15 members of the finance committee and five of them-not all simultaneously-have been identified as people who flogged companies to the Maher organ- isation.

SPEECH.PARA: Far from saying that one is paranoid to suspect that the Liberal Party might be a little sympa- thetic to the interests of people who flogged companies to the Maher organisation, it seems to me that one would have to be pretty thick if one did not come to that conclusion, particularly as the only company of which we have details-the other companies were incorporated in Western Australia and, therefore, have not been investigated yet-of a sale to the Maher organisation by members of the finance committee of the Western Australian branch of the Liberal party is Treamog Pty Ltd. That is the only company of which we have financial details. That company had a current year profit of in excess of $3.7m. Its balance sheet, presented a month or so before it was sold, showed a provision for taxation of $2.168m, none of which has been paid. Senator Crichton-Browne must think that we are extraordinarily gullible and that the people of Australia are extraordinarily gullible, given the fact that five members of this finance committee have been identified as having sold companies to the Maher organisation, if he expects us to believe that this Government is not a little susceptible to a bit of pressure from people who have been involved in tax avoidance and evasion.

I return to the provision which we want to have reinserted in clause 4 of the Taxation (Unpaid Company Tax) Assessment Bill. It is a provision which the Government had in the Bill when it was introduced on 23 September. It does not make it mandatory for the Commissioner of Taxation to name people who have not paid tax, but it does make it much more likely that the Commissioner would name people-vendor-share-holders-who have not paid tax. I refer to the puerile argument put up in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) when he questioned why Ralph Willis, the honourable member for Gellibrand, wanted this provision to be inserted. Mr Spender said:
He does it simply for the purpose, so it would seem, of bringing pressure on people to pay. People should not pay because of public pressure, because of fear of trial in Parliament . . .

Leaving aside the last extravagant line-it is not a question of trial in Parliament; it is a question of information being disclosed by the Taxation Commissioner-what this man is saying is that people who have had the use interest free for anything up to 10 years of money that ought to have been paid in tax and who ultimately will not have to do anything more than pay back in inflated dollars-grossly devalued dollars-money that really ought to have been paid as far back as 10 years ago should not be publicly identified. He thinks it is intolerable that people who do not pay on time after receiving an assessment should be publicly identified. All our amendment, which the Government itself had in originally, seeks to do is to make that situation more likely. The people who have had the interest free use of money for 10 years will pay it back in today's value dollars and not in the much more valuable dollars of anything up to 10 years ago. Mr Spender thinks it is intolerable that people who are not paying up under those extraordinarily generous terms-providing they have managed to evade the liability completely through clause 3 sub-clause (12) of the Bill or some other device-should have any sort of pressure brought on them by way of being named in the report of the Commissioner of Taxation. One would have to be pretty gullible to swallow that line.

The Government has given no reasonable explanation at all for having changed its own original Bill. We seek to restore to this proposed new section the clause which was in the 23 September Bill. No reasonable explanation at all has been given for the decision to change it. I suggest to Senator Crichton-Browne that the obvious explanation is that his influential friends back in Western Australia successfully appealed to the natural sympathies of the Liberal Party for people who have been up to their necks in tax avoidance and tax evasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walsh's contribution appears to confirm a comment made by Senator Withers that some people regard this legislation as revenge legislation. I do not regard it as revenge legislation but apparently Senator Walsh does. I support the legislation because, simply stated, there have been people who, after having received advice, have entered into arrangements whereby they have received a tax benefit which they otherwise would not have obtained. All that this legislation does is establish a new tax in order to recover moneys and identify people involved. The new tax is thereby levied on them. Why should those people be treated in any different way from any other taxpayer? As the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) said, they have no chance of breaking this law because the tax will be levied. They will either pay up or not pay up.
