SPEECH.PARA: I am very concerned about the fact that over the past two or three months names of individuals have been bandied about under the cloak of parliamentary privilege and this Parliament itself has been held up to ridicule. I suggest to the Opposition that the stocks of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, have fallen amongst the general public because he also engaged in name calling and was found out. I suggest that Mr Hayden's reflections on John Reid did him no good at all. I do not think it affected John Reid's credibility or standing in the community but it did affect the Leader of the Opposition's standing in the community. My own view is that we should reject this clause if we are to treat this legislation in a proper manner and thus reject the revenge aspect that has been injected into this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that Senator Harradine has raised the question of vengeance. I only hope that all those Liberal senators who voted in the affirmative in the last division know what strange sorts of bedfellows they have in supporting this legislation. The only thing about Senator Walsh's amendment that surprises me is its mildness. I would have thought that at least he would have wanted the stocks re-erected. Does he want the debtors' prison of the fleet re-opened?
—The stock exchange.
—Yes, the stocks with people throwing rotten apples and cabbages .
—Liberal legislation.
—That is what this legislation is all about.
—It was in the original Bill. Who put it in there?

—Honourable senators opposite want vengeance. These are the sorts of people Liberal senators are getting into bed with. All honourable senators opposite want to do is pillory people in public. They want to put them in the stocks and throw muck at them. I would have thought-the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) will correct me or Senator Evans will, given half the chance-that once the Commissioner of Taxation has issued an assessment and there are no objections, boards of review or court proceedings on that assesment, on the assumption that the procedures have been completed, the taxpayer then owes a debt to the Crown. How does the Commissioner of Taxation collect this debt? He collects it by the normal processes of the law. He can either send a person bankrupt which happens quite often-a string of surgeons in Perth got mixed up in the Molle affair and were made bankrupt by the Commissioner of Taxation in an attempt to collect the taxes due-or other procedures are available to him. I do not know whether he can execute either on a person's goods or on his person prior to getting a judgement for the debt that is due. I imagine that the Commissioner uses the normal provisions of the law existing in this country to collect the money owing to him. I think Senator Missen, who no longer has those terrible priorities he used to have-or does he- did something about the priority of Crown debts.
—We tried.
—The honourable senator says that he tried. Did the honourable senator not succeed?
—We had a 50 per cent win.
—Good. That is better than nothing.
—We got rid of half the tax.

—Good. One complaint I have about the collection of debts from the private sector is that occasionally the debt collecting agencies go in for the harassment of debtors. For example, they park a van outside the debtor's house and say: 'We are here to collect money from people who do not pay their bills'. There has been a lot of harassment by debt collecting agencies. Most civilised people think that such conduct ought not to be permitted. It is only 100 odd years since the Dickensian method of gaoling people for debt was formally abolished-the old debtors Acts. Do we want to go back to that? I would have thought that the Commissioner ought to be in the same position as anybody else in the community in that he collects his debts in private, unless of course he sues in the public courts for them.
—Consenting acts you might say?

—Yes. Most of us pay our debts privately whether we get our bills from the Myer emporiums, David Jones Ltd, the Commissioner of Taxation, Bankcard or whatever we are using. We write cheques and we pay our bills. I imagine that the Commissioner of Taxation gets most of his money by the same means. The taxpayer gets an assessment, attaches a cheque to it and sends it off . I hope that the Commissioner of Taxation collects the money due to Consolidated Revenue by the normal methods used within the community. He ought not to be given powers beyond those of any other person to whom money is owed. I am not one of those people who believes that either the Crown, if one is a royalist, or the state, if one is a republican, should have more privileges than anyone else in the community. This is one of the things for which parliamentary democracy has been fighting certainly since about the time of the Magna Carta. These days we seem to be turning the clock back. I can understand that my socialist opponents have always believed the state to be more important than the individual.
—Nonsense-stuff and nonsense.

—Oh well, there is the civil libertarian who will come in here and vote for legislation because his Caucus instructs him to do so. He will come in here and be a good little boy because there are no civil liberties in the Australian Labor Party, none whatsoever. If you were in government there is no way that you would have one of your back benchers getting up making these sorts of speeches.
—Order! Senator Withers, would you address your remarks to the Chair, please.

—Yes, Madam Temporary Chairman. Why should the Crown's money be any more sacred than anybody else's money? Is it not one of these peculiar things we have in society at the moment that the state, the all-powerful state--
—It is not the state; it is the community as a whole.

—There the honourable senator goes again identifying himself with the community. It does not matter how many individuals are crushed as long as we have the tyranny of the majority. It does not matter about individual rights. No mavericks and no eccentrics are allowed-take them out and shoot them. That is what is done in Russia. They have stamped out all the dissidents. No dissidents are allowed.
—How much did you tolerate when you were Leader?

—I tolerated the honourable senator. He is an interesting specimen and really ought to be in a bottle at the Academy of Science. He is no genie and ought to be snapped up forever. Madam Temporary Chairman, what Senator Walsh is attempting to do is to enforce the payment of money by terrorising people. I would have thought that the Labor Party would be the first to complain about any private creditor who attempted to get the money from his debtors by publishing their names or by pressure of that sort. In fact, I think some of those bad practices of debt collection agencies have been stamped out by legislation in some of the States. I would be very disappointed if the Commissioner of Taxation ever had to stoop to those levels to collect the money due to him. For those reasons the amendment ought to be opposed.

—I will just recap and rebut some of the observations Senator Walsh has again made with the normal enthusiastic gusto in attacking the Liberal Party of Australia. Let me just say from the outset that Senator Walsh has said that there are five members of the Liberal Party finance committee who are--
—Do you want their names?
—Yes, I do.
—How about Ron Woss for starters?
—He is not a member.
—I didn't say he was.

—The honourable senator did. Senator Walsh recently put out a newsletter-Senator Missen might be interested in this- which listed five members of the finance committee of the Liberal Party of Western Australia dating to 1979. He said: 'I would be very glad for any information I can get on any of these people, particularly the companies they may be involved with.' As a throw-away line his final comment was quite unrelated, but he said: 'Senator Durack's heart attack was the greatest plea for sympathy since Lindy Chamberlain 's pregnancy.' As far as I am concerned that sums up the approach of the Opposition to these matters. It is a reflection upon their newsletter. I find it very interesting that we get so many of these attacks upon the Liberal Party and upon Mr Horgan who has been found so far to be thoroughly innocent of any offence morally or legally. We hear very little of the member of the Australian Labor Party, the Mount Lawley branch member, who signed as a member of the Labor Lawyers League supporting--
—Who was that?

—Mr Bercove, who has been accused of actively being involved with his wife in something like 100 bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. He has been accused, fairly or unfairly, in being involved in prostitution. He has been accused, fairly or unfairly, of being involved in making decisions about taxation matters when he was involved in these activities. We hear nothing about that from Senator Walsh. I find it interesting that he says so little about that . I make no judgment about whether it is true--
—Order! Senator Crichton-Browne, could you direct your remarks back to the clause under discussion?

—I am seeking to do so. I am simply rebutting the irrelevant trivia we have heard so far from honourable senators opposite. The facts of the matter are that everything Senator Walsh has said so far has been throughly untrue, thoroughly irrelevant and thoroughly scandalous.
—I am sure Mr Bercove will be pleased to hear that Senator Crichton-Browne does not believe in abusing individuals in parliament.
—Order! Senator Walsh, will you direct your comments to the clause under consideration?

—Yes, Madam Temporary Chairman. The difference between the Government, Senator Harradine apparently, and the Opposition on this matter is very simple. We are dealing with people who, according to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), are frauds and criminals. Leaving that aside-
—The legislation doesn't say that.

—That is what the Prime Minister said. Senator Withers will not deny that, will he? I am not passing judgment. I am quoting what the Prime Minister regards these people as. We are certainly dealing with people, independently of the Prime Minister's views about them, who have had an interest -free loan for anything up to 10 years which they should not have had in the first place. In addition, these people are not even paying the money back on time when they get an assessment to pay money that they might have had for 10 years interest free, and which they should never have had. We do not believe there is anything improper about using pressure to make those people pay the money. The Government and, regrettably, Senator Harradine apparently believe it is improper to use pressure to make them pay back the money they should not have had and which they have had for anything up to 10 years interest free. I am surprised, I must say, that Senator Harradine does not think that the unemployed , for example, are not more deserving of sympathy than protecting from exposure people who are not paying back money which they should not have had when they have been formally obliged to do so.
—I don't know how that comes into it.

—It is a question of priorities. Senator Harradine is willing to go in to bat for people such as this. I think they are being treated extraordinarily generously. Even if pressure is put on them to pay back the money on time, they are still being treated with extraordinary generosity. I think the sympathy is, to say the least, misguided. I note that Senator Withers trotted out that old tory line about how socialists believe the state is more important than the individual. I have always found that remark particularly ironic coming from members of a political party that 10 years ago was conscripting kids to fight in Vietnam. The wicked socialists who were supposed to say that the state is more important than the individual were opposing conscription.
—Order! Senator Walsh, you are becoming a little irrelevant.
—Madam Temporary Chairman, you challenge me on grounds of relevance.
—Indeed I did.

—I concede you have a point. Senator Withers took the debate in this direction, not I. Nobody from the Government side has explained why, if the amendment we now propose is as dreadful as they would have us believe, it was in the Government's original Bill. I invite them to do so.

—I wish to point out how far-fetched Senator Walsh's comments were when he tried to devise arguments in favour of his amendment to the legislation. He brought into the debate, in some irrelevant fashion, the matter of the unemployed. He ought to know that I have been involved in assistance to the unemployed and in the labour movement for a lot longer than he has. I do make the point quite bluntly to emphasise the point that has been made by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) and Senator Withers, that quite clearly pressure will be applied on vendor- shareholders and promoters to pay the new tax that is levied under this legislation. The Commissioner of Taxation has available to him all of the legislation which would ensure payment, including sending the vendor- shareholders and the promoters bankrupt. If that is not a persuasive power in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation-it is far more persuasive than naming people in his annual report-I do not know what is.
—That is very public.
—As Senator Withers said, that is extremely public. I think that the case rests there. I am sure that under those circumstances this amendment will be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to the debate, particularly the speeches of Government senators, I think the record ought to be put straight. The amendment which has been moved by Senator Walsh states:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 8, clause 4, after sub-clause (3), insert the following new sub-clause :
''(3A) A report of the Commissioner under section 14 of the Assessment Act may-
(a) draw attention to the failure of a person to pay recoupment tax or late payment tax due and payable by the person; and
(b) disclose the identity of the person.''.

The speakers opposite have tried to vilify Senator Walsh and to portray this amendment as being his. What Senator Walsh is endeavouring to do by moving this amendment is to re-insert in the Bill a clause which was in the original Bill. There is no doubt that the Bill would have gone through the Liberal Party and National Party rooms. Members of those parties would have talked about it. It came into the other place and because of pressure upon the Government, which was brought to bear by the very people Senator Walsh mentioned, the Government has decided to delete the clause. To save the Government some embarrassment Government senators tonight tried to portray to the people at large that this is an amendment of Senator Walsh or of the Opposition. It is no such thing; it was in the original Bill. If people look at the original Bill they will see this. It was put there by the Government-no doubt by the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-and agreed to by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and brought into the other place. Because of the pressures brought upon the Government by the powers that be, the very people who Senator Walsh is criticising, the clause was taken out of the Bill to appease those people who no doubt have been heavy financial contributors to the Liberal Party, particularly in Western Australia, as my colleague Senator Walsh has pointed out.

One thing has come out of this amendment which has been moved by Senator Walsh tonight. It reminds me of that book about Ben Chifley, The Light on the Hill, in which it was mentioned that the greatest thing that could happen to make people come out of their cocoons is when the hip-pocket nerve pinches. That is the very thing that has happened tonight. Senator Withers made one of the longest speeches in this chamber tonight on this Bill. Because the hip-pocket nerve is pinching on some of his friends Senator Withers saw fit to come out of hibernation, out of his cocoon, to make a speech. I think it is perhaps the first speech of any length that he has made since he was deposed from the leadership in this place by Mr Fraser. I give Senator Withers credit. I thought that he suffered from permanent laryngitis but we find tonight that he does not. He has come out of his cocoon in defence of the people in Western Australia whom both Senator Withers and Senator Crichton-Browne are desperately trying to defend.

In trying to defend those people they are trying to lay all of the blame on the shoulders of Senator Walsh who, in my view, has been honest in what he is trying to do; to re-insert in the Bill the very clause which the Government saw fit to take out. It is an embarrassment to the Government. Senator Withers said that some Government senators ought to be ashamed because they are sitting with strange bedfellows because the Opposition is voting with the Government. It is not our Bill. It is the Fraser Government's Bill. It is not the Labor Party's Bill. I find it hard to appreciate what Senator Withers is about when he tries to turn the debate around and accuses some of his own senators of being with strange bedfellows just because the Labor Opposition supports the Government's Bill.

It is very interesting to sit here tonight and to see the disarray on the Government side. We have heard Senator Crichton-Browne airing a great difference of opinion with Senator Missen. I have always looked upon Senator Missen as one who considers things in a rational manner. However, because he comes up with a point of view which is different from that of Senator Crichton-Browne we see Senator Crichton-Browne shaking his finger at him and making certain accusations about him. I give great credit to Senator Missen. I am only imitating Senator Crichton-Browne, who was trying to embarrass Senator Missen here tonight. I am sure he could not do that. If any honourable senators in this chamber have been embarrassed tonight by Senator Walsh's amendment they would be Senator Crichton- Browne and, not very far behind him, Senator Withers. We only have to have listened to them tonight or to read the record of the debate tomorrow--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I ask what relevance Senator McLaren's speech has to the matter before the chamber.
—Senator Jessop, I was about to invite Senator McLaren to come back to the clause which is the subject of debate before the Committee.

—Mr Chairman, I think that when the Hansard is read tomorrow it will be seen that I have mentioned the amendment moved by Senator Walsh more often in the five minutes I have been speaking then did either Senator Crichton- Browne or Senator Withers. We know that Senator Jessop was not in the chamber at the time, so he would not know. I invite him to read the Hansard tomorrow to see how often I mentioned that amendment and how often I addressed my remarks to it. I say again that the amendment moved by Senator Walsh in fact embraces a clause which appeared in the original Bill brought in by the Fraser-Howard Government in trying to deal with these crooked tax evaders-they are nothing else. I say again, in support of Senator Walsh, that the senators who vote against Senator Walsh's amendment tonight are in support of tax evaders in this community. It is the lower-paid income earners who will have to contribute by paying higher taxes in order that the wealthy people who support the Liberal Party can be let off the hook and so make a contribution to that party's election funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Withers Sen The Rt Hon R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance ( Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) for information from her advisers on this matter. If any taxpayer fails to pay any tax on the date on which it is due, I take it that the Commissioner of Taxation has two courses of action open to him. One is to issue a bankruptcy notice, which is very, very public and identifies the person. I take it that the other course open to him is to sue for his money by the issue of a writ, which again makes very public the sum owing and the identity of the individual. Does the Commissioner have any other capacity to collect his money? I assume he collects it by due process of law through the bankruptcy courts or the normal courts by suing for the amount owed. If he does that, I suggest to Senator McLaren that it makes very public who the individual is and how much money is involved. I imagine the Commissioner can, and should, do that the day after the sum falls due.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this clause has had a fair bit of discussion. Senator Withers or someone else made these points before to the effect that the Commissioner of Taxation has powers to collect the money. Of course, he would sue through the courts. He would get judgment. He has garnishee powers, or he can put a person through bankruptcy proceedings. Those courses are open to the Commissioner. As I said earlier and as I think other honorable senators have mentioned, failure to pay has not been regarded as a breach or evasion warranting the naming of a person by the Commissioner. It was for that reason that the Government decided that this provision to entitle the Commissioner should not be inserted in the Bill. That was said many times before Senator McLaren and others got up to talk about it. The usual processes of the collection powers of the Commissioner of Taxation are available and it is for that reason that it seems unnecessary to extend the Commissioner's reporting function that presently exists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Withers for drawing attention to the fact that people who do not pay their tax on time can be sued for recovery or can be bankrupted and that in both cases the proceedings are very public and the people concerned are named. In that case I wonder why there is so much passionate opposition from Senator Withers and his friends to naming in the Taxation Commissioner's report people who have not paid their tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 4 agreed to.
Clause 5 (Primary taxable amounts).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 16, clause 5, sub-clause (7), paragraph (c), sub-paragraph (ii), line 44, after ''expected'' insert ''by the person or persons who sold shares''.
(2) Page 17, clause 5, sub-clause (7), paragraph (c), sub-paragraph (iii), line 6, after ''expected'' insert ''by the person or persons who sold shares''.
(3) Page 17, clause 5, sub-clause (9), paragraph (c), leave out the paragraph.

The purpose of these amendments is to help the Government resolve some inconsistencies in the legislation, in the first instance by adding the words ' by the person or persons who sold shares'. That in no way alters the intention of what the Government is trying to do because as the clause is printed there is a degree of ambiguity as to from whom the liability is owing. Sub-clause (7) (c) (ii) states:

any amount of ordinary company tax (not including additional tax payable inder section 207 of the Assessment Act) that, immediately before the last sale time, might reasonably have been expected to become payable by the company at a later time in relation to the year of income in which the last sale time occurred or a preceding year of income . . .

There is an area of ambiguity there which cropped up when we dealt with the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act of 1980 as to who is the person affected. It is very clear, from what the Government has said on this, that it believes the vendors of those shares are the people who should meet the liability. By inserting those words-there is no reason why the Government would oppose this- that ambiguity would be resolved. There are good and sound reasons for that matter to be resolved at this point.

The third amendment, which deals with the second theme, resolves the inherent inconsistency and incompatibility between what is said in clause 5 (7) (c) (ii) and clause 5 (9) (c) because the former sub-clause provides that the taxation liability shall be in the line of what would reasonably be expected to be the taxation liability of the company, presumably when the assessment is issued, which would be at the end of the financial year. Many changes can take place through a financial year and it may well have been known to the vendors of the shares that through the rest of the financial year the taxation liability of the company would have altered from what it was at the time of sale. Again that is a reasonable proposition for the Government to accept. But when we go to clause 5 (9) (c) we find that it is worded in such a way that the taxation liability of the company is assessed prior to the sale of the shares. In other words, a vendor who sold in good faith knowing that there would be a change in tax liability will have no recourse to what sub-clause (7) (c) (ii) provides because clause 5 (9) (c) denies him that right. It is a fundamental drafting error in the Bill. Therefore, I look forward to the support of the Government for my amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not support the amendments that have been moved by Senator MacGibbon. The amendments to which he has just referred relate to those provisions of the Bill which define the method of calculating the company's contingent tax liability at the date of sale. The contingent tax liability of the company is used in ascertaining whether the excess consideration test in sub -clauses (1) and (2) of clause 5 is met. The ascertainment of the contingent tax liability of the company is an objective one. The insertion of the words 'by the person or persons who sold shares' would result in the test becoming subjective. In other words, the actual expectation of a vendor-shareholder would be required . To the extent that it requires an ascertainment of a vendor-shareholder's state of mind it could lead to claims that there was no subjective expectation of a tax liability because the vendor-shareholders were told that their company was to be put through a magic trick to eliminate that liability. Of course, there was no magic trick; there was simply fraud.

SPEECH.PARA: Viewed in another way, the amendments proposed by Senator MacGibbon amount to an innocence clause. The Government does not accept the validity of arguments for an innocence clause. We will probably be saying something further on that matter shortly. The omission of paragraph (c) of clause (5) (9) would also enable claims that post-sale tax avoidance schemes were to be used to eliminate liability and would also, in effect, amount to an innocence exclusion. For those reasons, the Government is not able to accept the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a rather interesting explanation. I presume that the person who wrote it is the person who drafted this part of the Bill. What we are doing here is imposing more draconian penalties on people after this Bill is passed and applying them for the period of 10 years before the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act than existed after that Act was passed two years ago. I should have thought that it would be very difficult for the Government to sustain that position. I would like to have a word with the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) about this business of everyone being presumed guilty. That is the presumption that she has made. She cannot seem to understand that some people would have legitimate and bona fide tax deductions for the rest of the financial year. I would like the Minister to explain why all the people involved are presumed to be guilty of fraud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know when Senator MacGibbon prepared his amendments but I had not seen them until tonight. I have not had the opportunity to take any expert advice on them. Senator Evans is objecting. He has had a quick look at them. Certainly, nothing that Senator MacGibbon has said convinces me that the amendments should be supported. In the first two amendments he seeks to insert the words 'by the person or persons who sold shares' following the words 'might reasonably be expected'. I am only a layman in these matters but it seems to me that if words mean anything at least the possibility of litigation is opened up by the insertion of those words. The test then becomes not what might be reasonably expected by a third part standing at arm's length in the transaction but what a person who was involved in the transaction says was reasonably expected of him.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the third amendment, which seeks the deletion of sub-clause 9 (c) entirely, I repeat that the Queen's Counsel to whom I was recently speaking said that this Bill seems to be written in a mixture of Swahili and Afghan and it is terribly hard to understand. But again Senator MacGibbon has not, in my view, given sufficient reason for supporting that amendment either. The Opposition will not support any of the amendments. I point out that the Bill has been around for a very long time. We all know, of course, that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said in July that this Bill would be passed in the first two weeks of the Budget session; that is, the Bill would have been passed through both Houses before 24 August. In fact, the first version did not hit the deck until 23 September and the second version did not hit the deck until 23 October, which was five weeks ago. If Senator MacGibbon wanted more thorough consideration given to his amendments he should have circulated them before 8 o'clock tonight.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator MacGibbon's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Radio-telephone Communications: Privacy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 May I raised a matter relating to the eavesdropping of telephone conversations between Weipa and Aurukun. I outlined that I had been advised that commercially available frequency modulation radios can monitor conversations on this radio telephone link. To date I have not been told of the outcome of any investigation into the matter. Can the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), who is in the chamber, provide any information now and, if not, can some information be provided in the near future?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the Hansard from 19 May. Senator Colston was kind enough to give me some warning that he would be raising this matter. There is no doubt, on reading that Hansard , that Senator Colston set out, on that occasion, a situation. I undertook to try to get some information for him. I believe that it is quite right and proper that he raises the matter again tonight. I think a period of six months has passed since he first raised it. Tonight we have been back to the Department which I represent and have gone as far as we can to try to get some information. I can give him some general information at this stage. I am advised that some radio circuits are not absolutely private; that conversations can be heard by people using the right equipment and with the willingness to eavesdrop; that in remote areas such as Weipa and Aurukun the terrain is such that Telecom Australia is not able to provide secure landline circuits. The honourable senator, knowing the terrain, would understand that. Instead, Telecom uses radio links to provide a basic low cost service. A decision is best made at the time of installation whether some form of privacy protection device should be incorporated in the service. Such a device can be installed later in some particular cases, but it is more costly if it is done afterwards than if it is done at the time of installation.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, at Weipa and Aurukun the installation is such that conversations can be overheard by some people. I am not certain that that advice is based upon what the honourable senator told me or whether it is based upon further investigations. But Telecom is examining the matter urgently and it hopes to be able to come back to me with more information which I could give to Senator Colston, I hope, tomorrow. We do not have the extra information required tonight . The practice of listening in, eavesdropping, is of course illegal. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act was passed for the very purpose of stopping this despicable practice and it provides for severe penalties for people caught contravening the Act. There is then another line of action which might be opened up from what Senator Colston has described. May I say again that on reading the Hansard of 19 May I believe the honourable senator deserves and requires an answer to his problems. We are seeking that answer urgently and I will provide it as soon as I can.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.7 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 12 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Health monitor the need for podiatry in Australia and the extent to which these needs are met.
(2) What programs to assist in meeting that need are funded by the Australian Government through the Department of Health.

(3) Did the Evaluation and Grants Section of the Department of Health reject an application by Miss S. Marr to conduct a research study on the manpower requirements and the need for podiatry services in the community, if so, what was the reason for the rejection.
(4) Is any comparable study being undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My Department does not monitor the need for podiatry in Australia or the extent to which these needs are met.
(2) No programs are funded by my Department to assist in meeting these needs.

(3) Yes. Miss S. Marr submitted an application to my Department for a health services research and development grant on 14 January 1982. The application was entitled 'The evaluation of manpower requirements and the need for podiatry services in the community' and a sum of $9,500 was sought. Owing to the freeze on Commonwealth Government expenditure, the application was not formally considered by the Health Services Research and Development Grants Task Force till 5 August 1982. The Task Force did not recommend funding on the following grounds:
(i) There was concern that the methodology proposed in the project would not yield results which would constitute a basis for estimating the national need for podiatry services.

(ii) The Health Commission of New South Wales is responsible for monitoring the adequacy of health services in New South Wales. A study such as that proposed by Miss Marr would not be beyond the resources of that Commission if the subject was of sufficient concern to it.
(4) I am not aware of any comparable study being undertaken.
